questions.text: An investigator is studying the growth pattern of a particular bacterial strain that caused a respiratory disease outbreak in children in rural Venezuela. The bacteria are found to be able to grow in a specialized culture that contains sheep blood, cystine, and potassium tellurite; the colonies are black and have a shining surface. The isolated bacteria are most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of respiratory disease in children. However, the bacteria will appear as granular, “fried egg” colonies when cultured on Eaton agar, rather than as black and shiny colonies on cystine-tellurite agar.

B) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila causes respiratory illnesses (e.g., Legionnaire disease, Pontiac fever), but infection occurs almost solely in adults. Moreover, L. pneumophila requires iron and cysteine on a charcoal yeast extract agar for growth, not the cystine-tellurite agar used for this patient's culture.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the cause of pulmonary tuberculosis, which these children may be at higher risk of given the increasing prevalence of M. tuberculosis in Venezuela. However, mycobacteria will appear as nonpigmented, rough colonies when cultured on Löwenstein-Jensen medium, rather than as black and shiny colonies on cystine-tellurite agar.
Image Description:

A culture of M. tuberculosis in a petri dish on agar

After 3-4 weeks of incubation, characteristic rough, cauliflower-like, whitish-yellow colonies appear.

The complex waxy, lipid-rich cell wall of M. tuberculosis is hard to overcome for nutrients, which is why the reduplication time amounts to 12-18 hours and incubation lasts at least 3-4 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a common cause of respiratory disease in children. However, the bacteria will appear as round white-grey colonies when cultured, not as the black and shiny colonies seen in this patient. Moreover, the preferred medium is chocolate agar, which is prepared with heat-lysed horse (or sheep) blood, rather than the cystine-tellurite agar used in this patient's culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis is the cause of whooping cough, a respiratory disease that most commonly occurs in children. However, B. pertussis grows in small, grey-white, glistening colonies, not the black colonies seen in this patient. Moreover, the culture media of choice are the Bordet-Gengou or Regan-Lowe medium, not the cystine-tellurite agar used in this patient's culture.

F) CORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a gram-positive bacillus that is usually transmitted via respiratory droplets and causes diphtheria. Infection is rare in the United States because of vaccination (e.g., DTaP); however, diphtheria can spread rapidly in under-vaccinated areas of the world such as rural Venezuela. Cultures should be collected prior to the administration of antibiotics and the media of choice are cystine-tellurite agar or Löffler medium. Cystine-tellurite agar enables the growth of pathogenic corynebacterium species while suppressing diphtheroid growth, yielding black shiny colonies as seen on this patient's culture.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph (methylene blue stain)

Numerous gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria can be seen (examples marked by blue overlay). The pathogens exhibit pleomorphism and do not show a particular arrangement.
The bacterial poles appear nodular (exampled indicated by arrow-heads). The nodules usually contain granules, which can be made visible with special metachromatic stains (not shown here).

G) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae causes respiratory illnesses; however, infection typically occurs in hospitalized or immunosuppressed adults. Furthermore, gram-negative rods such as K. pneumoniae, Escherichia coli, and Salmonella species grow as metallic green colonies on eosin-methylene agar, rather than as black colonies on cystine-tellurite agar.
questions.hint: Microscopic examination of the organism on Löffler medium would show club-shaped bacteria with intracellular metachromatic granules.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of fever, headache, coughing, and thick nasal discharge. She had a sore throat and nasal congestion the week before that had initially improved. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Physical exam shows purulent nasal drainage and tenderness to percussion over the frontal sinuses. The nasal turbinates are erythematous and mildly swollen. Which of the following describes the microbiological properties of the most likely causal organism?

choices.text: Gram-positive, anaerobic, non-acid fast branching filamentous bacilli

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Moraxella catarrhalis (gram-negative, oxidase-positive, maltose-nonfermenting diplococci) is a relatively common cause of acute otitis media and the third most common cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is also a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, maltose-nonfermenting diplococcus. However, it is not a cause of acute rhinosinusitis.

B) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (gram-positive, optochin-sensitive, lancet-shaped diplococci) is the most common cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis. A viral upper respiratory infection, as this woman likely had the week prior, is the most common predisposing factor to the development of bacterial rhinosinusitis. The second most common cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis is nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae. Together, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae account for ∼ 75% of all cases.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Streptococcus (Gram stain)

The chains of bluish-purple (gram positive) cocci seen on this Gram stain are characteristic of the genus Streptococcus.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (gram-negative, lactose-nonfermenting, blue-green pigment-producing bacilli) is a common cause of nosocomial UTIs and pneumonia. It can cause a nosocomial rhinosinusitis in immunocompromised patients or those with nasal tubes (i.e. nasogastric tube), but this woman does not have any of those predisposing factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae (gram-negative, encapsulated, lactose-fermenting bacilli) can, in certain circumstances, cause a nosocomial bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, this patient has not been to the hospital recently. Additionally, K. pneumoniae is more typically the cause of nosocomial UTIs and pneumonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus (gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci found in clusters) is detectable in the nostrils of about 30% of the healthy population, but is a rare cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis. S. aureus is a common cause of skin infections (e.g. cellulitis, impetigo, abscess).
Image Description:

Colorized scanning electron micrograph

S. aureus is spherical and forms grape-like clusters (the word Staphylococcus name derives from the Greek word "staphyle" = bunch of grapes). This characteristic distribution pattern arises because Staphylococci replicate randomly in all directions; the bacteria themselves are, however, immotile.

F) INCORRECT:

Actinomyces israelii (gram-positive, anaerobic, non-acid fast branching filaments) is a natural bacteria of the oral cavity that causes abscess formation after tooth extraction, dental caries, or maxillofacial trauma. This type of bacteria does not cause acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.
questions.hint: The patient's fever, frontal headache, and purulent nasal discharge following an initial episode of symptoms suggestive of a viral upper respiratory infection indicates acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of burning with urination and purulent urethral discharge for the past 3 days. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. Several months ago he was diagnosed with urethritis caused by gram-negative diplococci and received antibiotic treatment with complete resolution of his symptoms. A Gram stain of the patient's urethral discharge shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which of the following properties of the infecting organism most contributed to the pathogenesis of this patient's recurrent infection?

choices.text: Production of enzymes that hydrolyze urea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expression of beta-lactamase genes is common to many bacteria, especially gram-negative and anaerobic organisms. The enzymes provide resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics. This patient was successfully treated for his initial infection with N. gonorrhoeae (likely with the beta-lactam antibiotic ceftriaxone, the first-line treatment). Therefore, it is unlikely that beta-lactamase expression played a role in reinfection.

B) INCORRECT:

N. gonorrhoeae is a facultative intracellular organism, as it resides and replicates within neutrophilic granulocytes (and epithelial cells) to evade the immune system. Although the intracellular nature of this pathogen contributes to its ability to establish infections, it does not enhance its ability to reinfect the same host after successful antibiotic treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

The synthesis of a polysaccharide capsule is an important virulence factor for Neisseria meningitidis as it enables the pathogen to evade phagocytosis. However, this patient has an infection with N. gonorrhoeae, which does not produce a capsule.

D) INCORRECT:

Although N. gonorrhoeae does, in fact, express immunogenic proteins, these can be masked to evade host immune response. This patient's reinfection is better explained by a different characteristic of the causal organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Production of enzymes that hydrolyze urea is an important virulence factor for urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis and H. pylori. Urease catalyzes the conversion of urea to ammonium (and CO2), which raises the surrounding pH and enables survival in an acidic environment. N. gonorrhoeae, however, does not produce urease.

F) CORRECT:

Pili are an important virulence factor that mediate the attachment of N. gonorrhoeae to the epithelial cells of a host. Anti-pilin antibodies that are directed against specific pilus proteins can prevent attachment of the pathogen. To circumvent this host immune response, N. gonorrhoeae utilizes DNA recombination to create a high frequency of antigenic variation of expressed pilus proteins; these proteins thus are no longer recognized by the initial antibodies. This particular virulence factor has made it difficult to create a vaccine that targets the gonococcal pili.
Image Description:

Colorized scanning electron micrograph of a laboratory culture

There are coffee bean-shaped diplococci with pili extending from their surface.
questions.hint: This patient's burning sensation with urination and Gram stain results (gram-negative intracellular diplococci) are consistent with gonococcal urethritis. Neisseria gonorrhoeae has developed several virulence factors that prevent host immune recognition.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with aortic valve disease is admitted to the hospital for a 3-week history of progressively worsening fatigue, fever, and night sweats. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows a systolic murmur and tender, erythematous nodules on the finger pads. Blood cultures show alpha-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci that are catalase-negative and optochin-resistant. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus and the most common cause of acute infective endocarditis. It is catalase-positive and beta-hemolytic, unlike the pathogen seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a catalase-negative, gram-positive coccus that can cause tonsillitis, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever. It can be differentiated from the pathogen in this patient because it is beta-hemolytic.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus gallolyticus, like all streptococci, is a catalase-negative, gram-positive coccus. However, it is usually beta-hemolytic or gamma-hemolytic. S. gallolyticus is an uncommon cause of subacute endocarditis (less than 5% of cases).

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is an alpha-hemolytic, catalase-negative, gram-positive coccus. It can be differentiated from the pathogen seen in this patient because it is optochin-sensitive. Moreover, it is an uncommon cause of infective endocarditis (less than 5% of cases).

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a gram-positive coccus that is part of the natural skin flora. Although S. epidermidis is a common cause of infective endocarditis in patients with foreign body insertions (e.g., peripheral or central venous catheters, surgical implants), it is catalase-positive and non-hemolytic, unlike the pathogen associated with this patient's condition. Furthermore, it is an uncommon cause of subacute endocarditis.

F) CORRECT:

Viridans streptococci are a group of alpha-hemolytic, optochin-resistant, gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal oral flora and a common cause of dental caries. In patients with damaged native valves, Viridans streptococci are the most common cause of subacute endocarditis. Treatment consists of penicillin or 1st or 2nd generation cephalosporins.
questions.hint: This patient presents with bacteremia and signs of subacute endocarditis. Dental procedures increase the risk of bacteremia with this organism.

questions.text: A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, headache, nausea, and a sore throat. Examination of the oral cavity shows enlarged, erythematous tonsils with exudates and palatal petechiae. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Her parents agree to her participating in a study of microbial virulence factors. A culture of the girl's throat is obtained and an organism is cultivated. The physician finds that the isolated organism is able to withstand phagocytosis when placed in fresh blood. The most likely explanation for this finding is the expression of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IgA protease, secreted by S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria species, inactivates IgA and allows bacteria to colonize mucous membranes. It does not inhibit phagocytosis. In addition, none of these organisms commonly cause pharyngitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Protein A inhibits phagocytosis by competitively binding to host immunoglobulins, and its expression could result in findings similar to those of the organism isolated by the physician. However, this virulence factor is produced by S. aureus. This patient's history and findings suggest infection with GAS, which does not produce protein A.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptolysin O, produced by GAS, lyses red blood cells and is responsible for β-hemolysis. It does not inhibit phagocytosis. Titers of anti-streptolysin O (ASO) antibodies increase following a GAS infection. While this can be used as evidence of a preceding GAS infection, the rapid group A streptococcus antigen detection test and/or throat culture are used in the diagnosis of active streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyaluronidase, produced by GAS, facilitates tissue invasion but does not inhibit phagocytosis. Hyaluronidase should not be confused with the hyaluronic acid capsule, another GAS virulence factor that encases the bacterium and inhibits phagocytosis by preventing macrophages from engulfing bacteria.

E) CORRECT:

M protein (virulence factor), a transmembrane protein expressed by GAS, blocks phagocytosis by inhibiting the alternative complement pathway, which is normally activated by microbial surface molecules. This virulence factor shares similar epitopes to human proteins, which is an example of molecular mimicry. Antibodies that form against M protein (virulence factor) enhance defense against GAS but cross-react with self-antigens in myocardium and nerves, which is thought to play an important role in the pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever.

GAS also has a hyaluronic acid capsule that inhibits phagocytosis by preventing macrophages from engulfing bacteria.

F) INCORRECT:

Erythrogenic exotoxin A, produced by GAS, causes toxic shock syndrome (TSS) through the release of several inflammatory mediators. This condition manifests with fever, septic shock, and an erythematous, macular rash. Although this patient has fever, she lacks the other characteristic features of TSS. Erythrogenic exotoxin A does not inhibit phagocytosis.
questions.hint: This girl's fever, sore throat, enlarged tonsils with exudates, palatal petechiae, cervical lymphadenopathy, and lack of cough suggest a diagnosis of bacterial tonsillopharyngitis. The most common cause of acute bacterial tonsillopharyngitis is group A streptococcus (GAS). The virulence factor responsible for the inhibition of phagocytosis in fresh blood is also directly involved in the pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of pain and swelling in his left leg that started after he cut his foot while swimming in the ocean. He has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis. His temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F). Examination of the left foot shows a small, purulent wound with surrounding swelling and dusky redness extending to the midcalf. There are numerous hemorrhagic blisters and the entire lower leg is extremely tender to light palpation. There is no crepitus. Blood cultures grow gram-negative bacilli that ferment lactose. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shigella flexneri is a gram-negative bacillus that causes shigellosis. S. flexneri can be transmitted through contaminated water but is not known to cause soft tissue infections, such as necrotizing fasciitis. Lastly, this pathogen is nonlactose fermenting, as opposed to the lactose-fermenting bacillus identified in this patient's blood cultures.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus that can cause a number of skin and soft tissue infections, including cellulitis, hot-tub folliculitis, and ecthyma gangrenosum, which can also present with necrotic skin lesions. Pseudomonas is commonly found in water but is nonlactose fermenting, as opposed to the lactose-fermenting bacillus identified in this patient's blood cultures.
Image Description:

Large necrotic ulcer with a purulent base and well-defined, hyperemic borders on the sternum of an elderly patient.

These findings are characteristic of ecthyma gangrenosum, a dermatologic manifestation associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia.

C) INCORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens can cause gas gangrene, a rare subtype of necrotizing fasciitis that can present similarly to this patient. C. perfringens is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacillus, as opposed to the gram-negative bacillus identified in this patient's blood cultures. Also, gas gangrene typically causes crepitus on palpation, which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Photograph of the right thigh of a male patient

There is tense edema of the right thigh and knee. Diffuse purplish-black patches are visible on the right inguinal region, thigh, and knee. Tense blebs of varying sizes filled with dark hemorrhagic fluid are present on the upper thigh and the knee.

These are the characteristic features of gas gangrene.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a common cause of cellulitis, which can develop into necrotizing fasciitis. However, S. pyogenes is a gram‑positive coccus, as opposed to the gram-negative bacillus identified in this patient's blood cultures.

E) CORRECT:

Vibrio vulnificus is a gram-negative, lactose-fermenting bacteria found in marine environments that can cause soft tissue infections, as well as gastroenteritis. V. vulnificus thrives in media with elevated serum ferritin and increased percentage of transferrin iron saturation. Therefore, patients with impaired iron metabolism (e.g., due to underlying liver disease) are at higher risk of developing severe infections (e.g., the necrotizing fascitis seen in this patient) and have higher mortality rates.
Image Description:

Posterolateral aspect of the left thigh, gluteal region, and popliteal fossa

There is significant diffuse edema and erythema across the entire visible region, with well-defined areas of necrosis, desquamation, and hemorrhagic bullae.

These features are strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis, a rapidly progressive infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and superficial and deep fascia that requires urgent debridement.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical signs of necrotizing fasciitis (e.g., severe pain, fever, dusky skin, blisters). His recent contact with seawater and history of cirrhosis suggests infection with a certain pathogen.

questions.text: A previously healthy 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain with urination. She has been sexually active with two partners over the past year. She uses condoms for contraception. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows suprapubic tenderness. Urinalysis shows neutrophils and a positive nitrite test. Urine culture grows gram-negative, oxidase-negative rods that form greenish colonies on eosin-methylene blue agar. Which of the following virulence factors of the causal organism increases the risk of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid is a structural protein in the cell wall of gram-positive bacteria. Although this molecule may act as an endotoxin in some gram-positive bacteria, the pathogen described here is a gram-negative organism.

B) CORRECT:

UPEC uses pyelonephritis-associated fimbriae (P-fimbriae) composed of glycoproteins to adhere to the urothelium, which promotes the colonization of the bacteria that leads to a UTI.

C) INCORRECT:

Biofilm-producing organisms that cause infection of the genitourinary system include Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This pathogen is the leading cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infection; it is an unlikely cause of this patient's uncomplicated UTI. Although Pseudomonas is a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium, it is oxidase-positive and does not produce green colonies on eosin-methylene blue agar. Other biofilm-producing organisms that are non-uropathogenic include Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus viridans, and nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae.

D) INCORRECT:

Lecithinase is produced by Clostridium perfringens, which is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacillus. However, this patient's uncomplicated UTI is caused by a gram-negative organism as suggested by her urine culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) are endotoxins that are released from the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria during cell lysis. In severe cases, significant levels of LPS subsequently trigger the host's immune system through activation of the complement cascade, resulting in septic shock. Although gram-negative bacteria were detected in this patient's urine, she presents with an uncomplicated UTI and not septic shock.

F) INCORRECT:

Injectisomes are present on some gram-negative, toxin-producing bacteria. Although this includes E. coli, which are gram-negative, oxidase-negative, rod-shaped organisms, injectisomes only occur in the EPEC and the EHEC strains of E.coli. These strains are known to cause GI disturbances including bloody diarrhea and are not commonly associated with UTIs.

G) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is produced by Neisseria gonorrhea, which is a common cause of sexually transmitted cervicitis and urethritis in adults. Gonococcal cervicitis and urethritis can present similarly to an uncomplicated UTI, with painful urination and suprapubic tenderness. However, Neisseria gonorrhea is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, intracellular diplococcus that does not form green colonies on EMB agar.
questions.hint: Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) are gram-negative, oxidase-negative bacteria that form green colonies on eosin-methylene blue agar and are the leading cause of uncomplicated urinary tract infection (UTI) in adults.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman from Ecuador is admitted to the hospital because of tarry black stools and epigastric pain for 2 weeks. The epigastric pain is briefly relieved after eating but worsens within 1–2 hours. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Fecal occult blood test is positive. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Biopsy of the gastric antrum and body is performed. Microscopic examination of the biopsy specimens is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

H. pylori is a spiral-shaped, flagellated gram-negative rod that mainly colonizes the antrum of the stomach. This bacterium is catalase positive, oxidase positive, and urease positive.
Image Description:

Scanning electron micrograph of helicobacter pylori

Multiple spiral-shaped bacteria with a length of 3μm and flagella are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Shigella species are short, nonflagellated gram-negative rods that produce Shiga toxin. They are obligate pathogens and cause fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. Shigella spp. are not associated with PUD.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a stool sample

Rod-shaped bacteria (examples in blue overlay) that also occasionally form short chains are visible. Erythrocytes (arrowheads indicate examples) and an inflammatory leukocytic exudate (examples in green overlay) can also be seen.

These findings are consistent with Shigella dysentery.

C) INCORRECT:

C. difficile is a drumstick-shaped, gram-positive rod that is part of the natural gut flora in 5% of adults. Although clostridium enterocolitis may lead to bloody diarrhea, the bacteria is not associated with PUD.

D) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci describes the histological findings of S. pneumoniae, which may cause many conditions (e.g., pneumonia, meningitis, sinusitis) but not gastrointestinal ulcers.
Image Description:

Scanning electron photomicrograph

A joined pair of spherical cocci (diplococci) is visible.

E) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a dimorphic budding yeast forming hyphae and long pseudohyphae. Candida albicans can cause esophagitis in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., HIV, transplant patients, diabetes mellitus) that can also lead to tarry stools if bleeding occurs, but it is not a common cause of PUD.
Image Description:

Typical rod-like, budding structure of Candida albicans (red overlay).

F) INCORRECT:

Giardiasis is a common parasitic infection caused by Giardia lamblia, which in their active form in the human body, appear as teardrop-shaped trophozoites. It presents with voluminous diarrhea characteristically consisting of frothy and greasy stools but is not associated with gastrointestinal bleeding or PUD.
Image Description:

Scanning electron micrograph

The trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia can be seen. Trophozoites are capable of reproduction and have two nuclei (N) in the ventral part as well as flagella (marked with arrows).
questions.hint: This patient presents with a bleeding duodenal ulcer found on esophagogastroduodenoscopy. The most common cause of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is infection with Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever and cough productive of foul-smelling, dark red, gelatinous sputum. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks two 12-oz bottles of beer daily. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavity with air-fluid levels in the right lower lobe. Sputum culture grows gram-negative rods. Which of the following virulence factors is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exotoxin A is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative rod that can cause a lung abscess secondary to pneumonia, especially in patients with alcohol use disorder. However, lung infection by P. aeruginosa is typically associated with green-colored sputum, not dark red sputum, due to the production of pyocyanin.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is secreted by Haemophilus influenzae (a gram-negative rod) and Streptococcus pneumoniae, both of which can cause a lung abscess secondary to pneumonia. However, Haemophilus influenzae infection is rarely seen in developed countries since introduction of the Hib vaccination, and Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive coccus.

C) INCORRECT:

Heat-stable toxins, such as the enterotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus, target the intestinal mucosa and cause food poisoning with enteritis. Although S. aureus can cause lung abscesses, heat-stable toxins are not responsible for the pathogenesis of pulmonary infections. Instead, other virulence factors, such as protein A, are involved in the pathogenesis of S. aureus pneumonia. Moreover, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus, not a gram-negative rod.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis-associated fimbriae (P-fimbriae) are present on uropathogenic E. coli. a gram-negative rod that causes cystitis and pyelonephritis. E. coli can also cause a lung abscess secondary to pneumonia, but E. coli pneumonia is typically hospital-acquired, and P-fimbriae are not responsible for the pathogenesis of pulmonary infections. Instead, other virulence factors, such as the K capsule, are involved in the pathogenesis of E. coli pneumonia.

E) CORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae possesses a capsular polysaccharide that acts as an antiphagocytic virulence factor and allows bacteria to evade host immune defenses. This pathogen is part of the natural flora of the gastrointestinal tract. In patients who are immunocompromised and patients who have an increased risk for aspiration events (e.g., due to chronic alcohol use), aspiration of Klebsiella can lead to destruction of alveoli, resulting in bloody sputum with a currant jelly appearance.
questions.hint: This patient's sputum culture with gram-negative rods and history of foul-smelling, dark red, gelatinous sputum (currant jelly sputum) is consistent with a pulmonary infection caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of an oozing skin ulceration on his foot for 1 week. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and does not adhere to his medication regimen. Physical exam shows purulent discharge from an ulcer on the dorsum of his left foot. Pinprick sensation is decreased bilaterally to the level of the mid-tibia. A culture of the wound grows beta-hemolytic, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters. The causal organism most likely produces which of the following virulence factors?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Protein A constitutes a major virulence factor of Staphylococcus aureus, the most likely underlying organism of this patient’s diabetic foot ulcer. Protein A impairs phagocytosis and opsonization of bacteria by interfering with the usual interaction between the Fc region of IgG antibodies and the complement system and Fc receptors on cell surfaces, thereby enabling evasion of the immune system.

B) INCORRECT:

P fimbriae are a major virulence factor of uropathogenic E. coli because they facilitate adherence to the urothelium. This results in urinary tract infections or pyelonephritis rather than skin infections. Moreover, E. coli is a gram-negative rod, not a coccus.

C) INCORRECT:

Exotoxin A, which causes cellular death through inactivation of elongation factor with subsequent impairment of protein synthesis, is a virulence factor produced by Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas is often implicated in hemorrhagic ulcers (ecthyma gangrenosum) and diabetic foot ulcers. However, Pseudomonas are gram-negative rods.

D) INCORRECT:

Urease yields ammonium and carbonic acid through cleavage of urea, thereby increasing the pH of the environment. This is beneficial for the growth of several bacteria such as Nocardia and Peptostreptococcus, which can cause cutaneous infections and ulcers. However, Nocardia is a gram-positive rod, not a coccus. Peptostreptococcus, on the other hand, are cocci but they are gamma-hemolytic, coagulase-negative, and appear in chains rather than clusters.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is a potent virulence factor produced by S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria species. It allows for adherence of the invading organism to mucosal surfaces through cleavage of IgA. However, none of these bacterial species are common in diabetic foot wounds, and none grow as beta-hemolytic, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters.

F) INCORRECT:

Streptococcal M protein, which inhibits phagocytosis and complement activation, is a major virulence factor of S. pyogenes. Even though this pathogen is a beta-hemolytic coccus that is associated with infected diabetic foot ulcers and ulcerating infections such as necrotizing fasciitis, it is coagulase-negative and grows in chains, not clusters.

G) INCORRECT:

Lethal factor, which is one of the three components of the anthrax toxin, causes host macrophage apoptosis. The anthrax toxin is the major virulence factor of Bacillus anthracis. Infection with B. anthracis is associated with exposure to livestock and typically manifests as a black, necrotic eschar, not an oozing ulcer. Moreover, B. anthracis is a gram-positive rod, not a coccus.
questions.hint: The most common pathogen isolated from diabetic foot ulcers is Staphylococcus aureus. The culture findings of beta-hemolytic, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters are consistent with infection by this organism.

questions.text: A 2980-g (6.6-lb) female newborn is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of worsening lethargy. The newborn was delivered at home 10 hours ago. The mother has had no prenatal care. The newborn's temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F). Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Her leukocyte count is 36,000/mm3 (85% segmented neutrophils). An organism is isolated from the blood. When grown together on sheep agar, the isolated organism enlarges the area of clear hemolysis formed by Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum is gram-positive, obligate anaerobic rods that cause botulism, which manifests with hypotonia, flaccid paralysis, and poor suck in newborns. Infantile botulism does not manifest with fever and signs of sepsis, and this infant has no risk factors for botulism (e.g., exposure to spores contained in honey). While C. botulinum is a β-hemolytic pathogen, this patient's blood culture findings suggest a pathogen that produces CAMP factor, which is not typical for Clostridium botulinum.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is not a common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis, and this patient lacks risk factors for neonatal P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., birth weight < 1500 g, intensive care unit stay). While P. aeruginosa is a β-hemolytic pathogen, this patient's blood culture findings suggest a pathogen that produces CAMP factor, rather than P. aeruginosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes are gram-positive, intracellular rods that occasionally cause neonatal sepsis (especially during outbreaks of listeriosis). Although L. monocytogenes is a weakly β-hemolytic pathogen that is CAMP factor positive, another pathogen is much more likely to have caused this patient's symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a β-hemolytic and catalase-negative bacteria. S. pyogenes may form the clear area of hemolysis on blood agar, as seen in this patient, but will not enlarge the area of hemolysis formed by Staphylococcus aureus, as it lacks the CAMP factor produced by the causal organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptocccus pneumoniae is not a common cause of neonatal sepsis. These α-hemolytic and catalase-negative bacteria cause a greenish discoloration on blood agar due to partial reduction of hemoglobin, unlike the clear area of hemolysis formed by the causal organism in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae (i.e., group B streptococcus (GBS)) is a β-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci that colonizes the vaginal mucosa and is among the most common causative pathogens of early-onset neonatal sepsis. Routine pregnancy screening at 36+0 to 37+6 weeks of gestation with rectal and vaginal swabs is recommended. Transmission of GBS to neonates can be prevented via administration of intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis. This patient's lack of prenatal care increased her child's risk of GBS sepsis.

Common causes for early-onset neonatal sepsis include chorioamnionitis and bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract with intrapartum pathogen transfer to the infant.
Image Description:

Bacterial culture (grown on Columbia horse blood agar)

Left: α-hemolysis
Partial hemolysis produces a greenish intermediate product. α-hemolytic Streptococcus species are called viridans streptococci (from Latin “viridis,” green), the most common being S. pneumoniae.

Middle: β-hemolysis
Complete hemolysis manifests as translucent agar. β-hemolytic Streptococcus species can be classified according to Lancefield groups (clinically relevant: A and B), S. pyogenes (group A) being the best known.

Right: γ-hemolysis
The term γ-hemolysis is a misnomer, as, in fact, no hemolysis takes place. The best known γ-hemolytic species are those of the Enterococcus genus.
questions.hint: This newborn's fever, lethargy, and elevated leukocyte count are concerning for neonatal sepsis, which is often accompanied by jaundice and dehydration. The causal organism produces CAMP factor, a protein that enhances the effect of β-lysin of S. aureus, thereby enlarging the area of clear hemolysis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room for a 6-hour history of fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination shows pooling of oral secretions and inspiratory stridor. Lateral x-ray of the neck shows thickening of the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds. Throat culture with chocolate agar shows small, gram-negative coccobacilli. The patient's brother is started on the recommended antibiotic for chemoprophylaxis. Which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Inhibition of prokaryotic DNA-dependent RNA polymerase is the mechanism of rifampin, the drug of choice for prophylaxis for Haemophilus influenzae. Side effects of rifampin include hepatotoxicity, development of red/orange bodily fluids, and cytochrome P450 enzyme induction. Rifampin may also be used for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis.
Image Description:

X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)

The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).

The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the 50S ribosomal subunit is the mechanism of action of certain antimicrobial agents, such as macrolides and clindamycin. Clindamycin is often used to treat methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), which rarely causes epiglottitis in children. Neither macrolides nor clindamycin are indicated for prophylaxis against H. influenzae.

An important side effect of clindamycin is the development of C. difficile colitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of prokaryotic topoisomerase II (gyrase) is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones. Fluoroquinolones such as ciprofloxacin can be used to treat urinary tract infections caused by gram-negative pathogens (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and atypical pneumonias (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). Ciprofloxacin can be used as prophylaxis for close contacts of patients infected with N. meningitidis – not H. influenzae.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the 30S ribosomal subunit is the mechanism of action of tetracyclines and aminoglycosides. Tetracyclines are used to treat Borrelia burgdorferi and Mycoplasma pneumoniae, among other atypical infections. Aminoglycosides are often reserved for serious gram-negative infections that are resistant to other broad-spectrum antibiotics. Neither tetracyclines nor aminoglycosides are indicated for prophylaxis against H. influenzae.

Major side effects of tetracyclines include photosensitivity reactions, teratogenicity, and damage to teeth/bones in children. Aminoglycosides have been implicated as ototoxins and nephrotoxins.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of peptidoglycan crosslinking is the mechanism of action of both cephalosporins and penicillins. Ceftriaxone can be used to treat meningitis caused by H. influenzae and amoxicillin is often used to treat mucosal infections caused by H. influenzae. However, neither penicillins nor cephalosporins are recommended for prophylaxis against this organism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the thumbprint sign (thickening of the epiglottis) on x-ray of the neck as well as classic clinical features (dysphagia, drooling, distress) of acute epiglottitis due to Haemophilus influenzae infection. The drug of choice for H. influenzae prophylaxis is rifampin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recent fatigue and weakness that is exacerbated by cross-country skiing. Four weeks ago, she was diagnosed with pneumonia; sputum cultures on Eaton agar showed organisms that lacked a cell wall. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and cyanosis of the fingertips. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypersegmented neutrophils are diagnostic of megaloblastic anemia. Causes of megaloblastic anemia include folate deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency. Although this patient’s presentation is consistent with anemia, megaloblastic anemia is not associated with M. pneumoniae infection.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A large granulocyte (dashed outline) with a hypersegmented nucleus (blue overlay) is surrounded by red blood cells.

The presence of hypersegmented granulocytes in a peripheral blood smear indicates megaloblastic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Denatured hemoglobin inclusions caused by oxidative stress can aggregate to form Heinz bodies. Heinz bodies and bite cells are characteristic findings in patients with G6PD deficiency. Although triggers of G6PD deficiency anemia include infection (as seen in this patient), this condition is an X-linked recessive disorder and therefore unlikely to manifest in a female patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (new methylene blue stain; high magnification)

Multiple erythrocytes are visible, some of which contain small, round inclusions (examples indicated by arrowheads) called Heinz bodies. Heinz bodies are composed of denatured hemoglobin and are typically associated with G6PD deficiency but are also seen in other conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

Microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes are most commonly seen in patients with iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). Individuals with IDA can present with chronic fatigue and pallor, which are present in this patient. However, IDA is not associated with or caused by a M. pneumoniae infection.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of basophilic granules in erythrocytes is known as basophilic stippling, which can be seen on peripheral blood smear of patients with sideroblastic anemia (e.g., due to lead poisoning) or thalassemia. Basophilic stippling is not associated with hematologic sequelae secondary to M. pneumoniae infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

The erythrocytes contain purple spots (green overlay), which are consistent with cytoplasmic granules. The large, heavily spotted cell in the center of the right image appears to be a neutrophil. In the center of the left image, there is a normoblast with a prominent nucleus, which is not usually present in peripheral blood and suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling describes the appearance of red blood granules, which are mainly composed of aggregating ribosomes. It is characteristic of impaired red blood cell maturation.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with the hallmark sign of cold agglutinin disease (acrocyanosis in response to exposure to cold temperatures). Cold agglutinins are cold-reactive IgM autoantibodies that are located on the surface of erythrocytes and may lead to an increased turnover of RBCs, resulting in hemolytic anemia. AIHA can be diagnosed with the direct Coombs test, which uses anti-human globulin (Coombs reagent) to bind autoantibodies attached to the patient's erythrocytes.

Cold agglutinin disease is associated with malignancy (e.g., CLL) and certain infections, including hepatitis C and infection with M. pneumoniae, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

A test used to detect hemolytic antibodies bound to RBCs (direct Coombs test) or freely circulating in the serum (indirect Coombs test).

1. The direct Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic antibodies or complement bound to the surface of a patient's erythrocytes. It is used to differentiate between autoimmune and nonimmune hemolytic anemias and to diagnose hemolytic diseases of the fetus and newborn.

2. The indirect Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic anti-RBC IgG antibodies (against foreign RBC antigens) present in a patient's serum. It is used to screen for maternal anti-D IgG antibodies (detection of hemolytic disease of the newborn) and to crossmatch blood before transfusions.
questions.hint: Eaton agar is used to grow Mycoplasma pneumoniae, which is associated with a certain type of anemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency room for severe left leg pain several hours after injuring himself on a gardening tool. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F) and his pulse is 105/min. Physical examination of the left leg shows a small laceration on the ankle surrounded by dusky skin and overlying bullae extending to the posterior thigh. There is a crackling sound when the skin is palpated. Surgical exploration shows necrosis of the gastrocnemius muscles and surrounding tissues. Tissue culture shows anaerobic gram-positive rods and a double zone of hemolysis on blood agar. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of cellular damage caused by the responsible pathogen?

choices.text: Degradation of cell membranes by phospholipase
Increase of intracellular cAMP by adenylate cyclase
Inactivation of 60s ribosome subunit by N-glycosidase
Inactivation of elongation factor by ribosyltransferase
Inhibition of neurotransmitter release by protease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endotoxin is a part of the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) component of gram-negative bacterial cell walls and causes cytokine release (IL-1, IL-6) as well as complement and macrophage activation. Clostridium perfringens (present in this patient's tissue culture) is a gram-positive bacteria and lacks LPS. Moreover, LPS-induced complement activation would result in hypotension and/or septic shock rather than gas gangrene.

B) CORRECT:

The alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens is a lecithinase that degrades cell membrane phospholipids. Degeneration of membrane phospholipids leads to cell lysis and myonecrosis, resulting in gas gangrene, as seen with this patient's bullous lesions and crepitus. Additionally, the lecithinase activity of this toxin causes hemolysis, which characteristically manifests as a double zone of hemolysis on blood agar.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased activation of adenylate cyclase and intracellular cAMP is mediated by the heat-labile toxin of enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). This overstimulation results in increased secretion of Cl- and H2O in the GI tract, causing watery diarrhea. This gram-negative organism is not associated with cutaneous infections or development of gas gangrene.

Several other bacterial toxins mimic adenylate cyclase activity. These include the edema toxin of Bacillus anthracis and the cholera toxin of Vibrio cholera. The heat-stable toxin of ETEC increases guanylate cyclase activity by increasing cGMP.

D) INCORRECT:

Shiga toxin produced by Shigella species inactivates the 60S ribosomal subunit of rRNA, which inhibits protein synthesis and causes enterocyte necrosis. This gram-negative bacteria is not associated with cutaneous infections or gas gangrene.

E) INCORRECT:

Exotoxin A is an AB toxin produced by several bacteria (Pseudomonas aeruginosa) that works by inactivating eukaryotic elongation factor-2 via ribosylation. Penetrative lesions in the lower extremities are classically associated with pseudomonal infections (and are fostered by high-moisture environments such as running shoes). Clostridium perfringens (present in this patient's tissue culture) produces a toxin that works via a different mechanism.

F) INCORRECT:

Tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani is a protease that cleaves SNARE proteins, which are required for neurotransmitter release. Clostridium tetani can also be contracted via traumatic body injury, often with old/rusty equipment. However, it does not cause gas gangrene or hemolysis, and classically presents with muscle spasms, lockjaw, and risus sardonicus.
questions.hint: This patient's myonecrosis is likely caused by alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens.

questions.text: A previously healthy 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department for a 2-day history of abdominal pain, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. Bowel movements occur every 3 hours and are non-bloody. He recently returned from a backpacking trip in Central America. He does not take any medications. Stool culture shows gram-negative, rod-shaped bacteria that ferment lactose. Which of the following toxins is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive bacillus that forms heat-stable spores and produces two different enterotoxins. One enterotoxin (cereulide) causes severe nausea and emesis 1–3 hours after ingestion of typically reheated starch-containing foods (e.g., rice), while the other results in watery, non-bloody diarrhea 8–16 hours after ingestion. This patient's stool culture shows gram-negative rather than gram-positive bacteria.

B) INCORRECT:

Vibrio cholerae is a gram-negative, flagellated, comma-shaped bacterium transmitted via fecal-oral contamination, primarily in developing countries. The bacterium produces cholera toxin, which increases intracellular cAMP and causes electrolyte (chloride) and water secretion into the intestine. This results in profuse, non-bloody diarrhea, often described as rice-water stools. In contrast to the stool studies in this patient, vibrio cholerae is a non-lactose fermenter.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and findings are consistent with enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) infection. ETEC is a gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium commonly transmitted by consumption of contaminated food in individuals traveling to Asian, African, and Latin American countries. ETEC produces both heat-labile toxin and heat-stable toxin. While heat-stable toxin increases cGMP via activation of guanylate cyclase, heat-labile toxin causes overactivation of adenylate cyclase, which increases cAMP. This results in increased chloride and water secretion into the intestine, causing watery, non-bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramping.

D) INCORRECT:

Clostridioides difficile is a highly contagious, gram-positive bacillus that forms heat-resistant spores, which are easily transmitted to hospitalized patients. This pathogen produces toxin A and toxin B. Toxin A binds to brush border enterocytes and causes fluid secretion into the intestine, resulting in profuse, watery diarrhea that is characteristically foul-smelling. This patient has no history of recent hospitalization or antibiotic use to suggest C. difficile infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria that can proliferate in inadequately refrigerated foods like mayonnaise and custard. This pathogen produces enterotoxin B, which causes severe vomiting within 2–6 hours of ingestion, followed by non-bloody diarrhea. This patient's stool culture shows gram-negative rather than gram-positive bacteria.

F) INCORRECT:

Shigella is a genus of gram-negative bacilli transmitted via the fecal-oral route or consumption of contaminated food. Shigella produces shiga toxin, an enterotoxin that causes enterocyte cell death and results in inflammatory, bloody diarrhea, as opposed to the non-bloody diarrhea seen in this patient.
questions.hint: E. coli is a common cause of non-inflammatory traveler's diarrhea.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain, night sweats, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past 4 weeks. She has rheumatoid arthritis treated with adalimumab. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows tenderness over the T10 and L1 spinous processes. Passive extension of the right hip causes pain in the right lower quadrant. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by an organism with which of the following virulence factors?

choices.text: Surface glycolipids that prevent phagolysosome fusion
Proteins that bind to the Fc region of immunoglobulin G

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A polysaccharide capsule that prevents phagocytosis is found in P. aeruginosa and Salmonella spp., which can cause osteomyelitis. However, pseudomonal osteomyelitis typically affects intravenous drug users and Salmonella osteomyelitis typically occurs in patients with sickle cell disease. These risk factors are not reported in this patient. The presence of constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest a different pathogen.

B) CORRECT:

The cord factor is a glycolipid in the cell wall of M. tuberculosis that inhibits phagosome-lysosome fusion and prevents lysis of phagocytosed mycobacteria. It has a synergistic effect with sulfatides, a sulfolipid virulence factor in M. tuberculosis that inhibits phagosome-lysosome fusion. This allows M. tuberculosis to survive in the phagosomes of macrophages. Cord factor also causes virulent M. tuberculosis bacilli to grow in a serpentine cord-like pattern and promotes the formation of granulomas by stimulating the release of TNF-alpha.

TNF-α plays an important role in the sequestration of M. tuberculosis in granulomas; inhibition of TNF-α results in the breakdown of granulomas and the release of mycobacteria, causing reactivation of latent TB. Patients receiving treatment with TNF-alpha inhibitors should be tested for infection with M. tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The virulence factor exotoxin A, which is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, impairs protein synthesis by inactivating EEF2. P. aeruginosa is a common cause of osteomyelitis in intravenous drug users. The presence of constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest a different pathogen.

D) INCORRECT:

The virulence factor protein A, which is produced by Staphylococcus aureus, binds to the Fc region of immunoglobulin G, thereby preventing opsonization and phagocytosis. S. aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis. However, the presence of constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest a different pathogen.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is a virulence factor that cleaves immunoglobulin A, which allows pathogens to adhere to mucous membranes. It is produced by various bacteria, including S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria species. Infection with N. gonorrhoeae can lead to septic arthritis and osteomyelitis of the spine, causing hip or lower back pain. However, this patient's constitutional symptoms following treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest infection with a different microorganism.
questions.hint: Fever, lower back pain, focal spinal tenderness, and a positive psoas sign are characteristic of vertebral osteomyelitis. Constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and fever as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor (adalimumab) suggest Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a sore throat and fever. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination shows edematous oropharyngeal mucosa and enlarged tonsils with purulent exudate. There is tender cervical lymphadenopathy. If left untreated, which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection and typically presents with fevers, diffuse rash, and shock from an overwhelming inflammatory response triggered by toxic shock syndrome toxin. Toxigenic strains of group A Streptococcus infection can cause scarlet fever or a toxic shock-like syndrome but is not associated with the development of true toxic shock syndrome.
Image Description:

Multiple partly confluent macules and papules, measuring 1–5 mm in diameter, are visible on the skin of this patient's left arm.

This finding is consistent with a maculopapular exanthema (a diagnostic criterium of toxic shock syndrome) caused by staphylococcus aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica is an autoimmune disorder that typically presents with proximal muscle pain and stiffness (predominantly affecting the shoulders) and elevated inflammatory markers and is strongly associated with temporal arteritis. Polymyalgia rheumatica can resemble migratory polyarthritis, which is a possible complication of this patient's suspected GAS pharyngitis, but GAS pharyngitis is not associated with the development of polymyalgia rheumatica.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by polyarthritis and morning stiffness. This patient's GAS pharyngitis does increase her risk of acute rheumatic fever and migratory polyarthritis, but would not increase her risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Dilated cardiomyopathy is a potential late and serious complication of acute rheumatic fever, a type II hypersensitivity reaction that can occur within 1–5 weeks after untreated GAS pharyngitis. Rheumatic heart disease can manifest in several ways, including myocarditis, pericarditis, and valvular disease (mitral valve involvement is the most common). The development of dilated cardiomyopathy is multifactorial and usually occurs secondary to valvular disease, but can also result directly from myocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme is a rash characterized by varying types of lesions, classically with target lesions (ring surrounding a dusky center). It is associated with several different infections, including Mycoplasma pneumoniae and HSV, as well as exposure to certain medications (phenytoin, NSAIDs, beta-lactam antibiotics, etc). GAS pharyngitis is associated with the development of erythema marginatum but is not a known cause of erythema multiforme.
Image Description:

Lower thigh and knee of a patient after antibiotic intake

Multiple erythematous, well-demarcated lesions can be seen. The lesions vary in size and shape, and some have merged to form larger lesions. The lesions show central erythema surrounded by a pale pink ring, characteristic of target lesions.
questions.hint: This patient has an acute infection of the oropharynx with odynophagia, fever, pharyngeal edema, cervical lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar hypertrophy with exudates. These features suggest group A streptococcal pharyngitis (GAS pharyngitis).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of fever, chills, and purulent drainage from a foot ulcer for 2 days. Her hemoglobin A1c was 15.4% 16 weeks ago. Physical examination shows a 2-cm ulcer on the plantar surface of the left foot with foul-smelling, purulent drainage and surrounding erythema. Culture of the abscess fluid grows several bacteria species, including gram-negative, anaerobic, non-spore-forming bacilli that are resistant to bile and aminoglycoside antibiotics. Which of the following is the most likely source of this genus of bacteria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The pathogen predominantly found in the stomach is Helicobacter pylori, a helix-shaped, gram-negative bacterium with flagella. The pathogen detected in this patient's wound is normally found elsewhere in the body.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal flora of the skin includes Staphylococcus epidermidis, Cutibacterium acnes, and Corynebacterium species as well as Micrococcus species. The pathogen detected in this patient's wound is normally found elsewhere in the body.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal flora of the vagina includes Lactobacillus spp. such as Lactobacillus acidophilus, a gram-positive, facultative anaerobe rod. The pathogen detected in this patient's wound is normally found elsewhere in the body.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal flora of the oropharynx includes Viridans streptococci and Neisseria species. The pathogen detected in this patient's wound is normally found elsewhere in the body.

E) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has a wound infection with Bacteroides fragilis, an anaerobic bacterium that is normally found in the colon. B. fragilis is a common pathogen in infected diabetic ulcers, particularly in the setting of a polymicrobial infection as seen in this patient. The additional infecting bacteria are necessary, as aerobic bacteria are required to create the tissue conditions necessary for an anaerobic infection.
questions.hint: Culture of this patient's abscess fluid grows Bacteroides species.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with ovarian cancer comes to the physician with a 5-day history of fever, chills, and dyspnea. She has a right subclavian chemoport in which she last received chemotherapy 2 weeks ago. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 115/min. Cardiopulmonary examination shows jugular venous distention and a new, soft holosystolic murmur heard best in the left parasternal region. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Echocardiography shows a vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Peripheral blood cultures taken from this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Gram-positive, catalase-negative, α-hemolytic, optochin-resistant cocci in chains
Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant cocci in clusters
Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters
Gram-positive, catalase-negative, nonhemolytic, salt-sensitive cocci in chains
Gram-positive, catalase-negative, β-hemolytic, bacitracin-resistant cocci in chains

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Viridans streptococci infection. However, these bacteria usually cause infection following dental procedures and afflict previously damaged native valves or prosthetic valves, neither of which are present in this patient. Moreover, Viridans streptococci typically cause subacute infection, whereas this patient presents with a 5-day history.

B) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Staphylococcus saprophyticus infection. This pathogen typically causes urinary tract infections rather than endocarditis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis, a bacterium commonly causing line-associated endocarditis, has similar microbiologic features but is novobiocin sensitive.

C) CORRECT:

The new holosystolic murmur in the left parasternal region and the echocardiographic findings indicate affliction of the tricuspid valve. Blood culture findings of gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters are characteristic of Staphylococcus aureus, which is the most common pathogen that causes acute infective endocarditis (including in patients with previously healthy valves).

In this clinical scenario, infection with Staphylococcus epidermidis would be a reasonable working diagnosis as well, especially since this bacterium is commonly responsible for infections via peripheral venous catheters. However, S. epidermidis is coagulase-negative.
Image Description:

Colorized scanning electron micrograph

S. aureus is spherical and forms grape-like clusters (the word Staphylococcus name derives from the Greek word "staphyle" = bunch of grapes). This characteristic distribution pattern arises because Staphylococci replicate randomly in all directions; the bacteria themselves are, however, immotile.

D) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Streptococcus gallolyticus infection. Infection with this bacterium is associated with colorectal cancer but not with ovarian cancer. Moreover, S. gallolyticus is only responsible for a small share of infective endocarditis cases and the gastrointestinal surface is a far more likely portal of entry than a central venous access.

E) INCORRECT:

The above microbiologic findings would indicate Streptococcus agalactiae infection. While this pathogen can cause respiratory symptoms in adults, it is usually responsible for neonatal infections (particularly neonatal meningitis). It is not associated with infective endocarditis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of infective endocarditis (2 major Duke criteria: a new valvular murmur, valvular vegetations on echocardiography). The chemoport is the most likely route of infection.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea that began 12 hours ago. Three days ago, she ate undercooked chicken at a local restaurant. Blood cultures grow spiral and comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organisms at 42°C. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Segmental myelin degeneration is the hallmark of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It is hypothesized that the inciting infection prompts the development of antibodies with cross-reactivity to antigens on Schwann cells. This molecular mimicry results in damage to the myelin sheaths of peripheral nerves. Campylobacter jejuni enteritis is classically associated with GBS.

B) INCORRECT:

Seizures can occur as a result of electrolyte imbalances in cases of profuse diarrhea (e.g., due to Vibrio cholerae infection). Vibrio cholerae is also oxidase-positive and comma-shaped but infection is typically contracted after eating undercooked seafood, and classically presents with copious watery diarrhea (“rice water diarrhea”), not bloody diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a serious complication of Clostridioides difficile colitis and also presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, the vast majority of patients with toxic megacolon caused by C. difficile have a history of recent antibiotic exposure. Moreover, C. difficile is a gram-positive, oxidase-negative, and obligate anaerobe bacillus that forms spores, unlike the spiral and comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organism found in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema nodosum can be a complication of Yersinia enterocolitica gastroenteritis, which can also present with abdominal pain and bloody or watery diarrhea after consumption of undercooked meat. However, Y. enterocolitica is an oxidase-negative pathogen that can grow at refrigeration temperatures (3–5 °C), unlike the pathogen seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Peyer patch necrosis can occur as a complication of typhoid fever and lead to profuse rectal bleeding. Infection with Salmonella typhi is via the fecal-oral route and would not be due to consumption of undercooked poultry. This infection develops over a period of weeks and is initially characterized by a fluctuating temperature with malaise, followed by profound fatigue and high fevers. Diarrhea is a relatively late finding. Moreover, Salmonella typhi is an oxidase-negative pathogen, unlike the oxidase-positive organism found in this patient.
questions.hint: Campylobacter jejuni is a spiral and comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organism that grows at 42°C and is a common cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea. It is associated with consumption of undercooked meat, especially poultry.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 1-day history of fever, shortness of breath, dizziness, and cough productive of purulent sputum. Six days ago, she developed malaise, headache, sore throat, and myalgias that improved initially. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F) and blood pressure is 84/56 mm Hg. Examination shows an erythematous, desquamating rash of the distal extremities. A sputum culture grows gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters. The most likely causal organism of this patient's current symptoms produces a virulence factor with which of the following functions?

choices.text: Binding of Fc domain of immunoglobulin G

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Degradation of membranous phospholipids is the toxic mechanism of alpha toxin, which eventually compromises cellular integrity. This leads to increased cellular permeability and hemolysis due to destruction of endothelial and blood cells, respectively. Alpha toxin, among several other degradative enzymes, is produced by C. perfringens. However, this pathogen is not associated with pneumonia or toxic shock syndrome, both of which are seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Binding of the Fc domain of immunoglobulin G is achieved by protein A, which promotes bacterial evasion of the host immune system. In the absence of protein A, an antibody's Fc domain is responsible for binding complement and interacting with Fc receptors on cell surfaces. Thus, protein A impairs phagocytosis, complement fixation, and antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity by successfully preventing the Fc region from attaching to its usual binding sites.

C) INCORRECT:

Overstimulation of guanylate cyclase is achieved by heat-stable enterotoxin in the setting of an infection with Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). Overactivated guanylate cyclase leads to a surplus of cGMP, which results in reduced resorption of electrolytes and water, causing diarrhea. This patient presented with pneumonia and toxic shock syndrome shortly after an episode of influenza, which is inconsistent with ETEC infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Destruction of immunoglobulin A is achieved by IgA protease, which subsequently allows bacterial pathogens to adhere to mucosal surfaces. IgA protease constitutes a major virulence factor in several bacteria, including S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae B, and Neisseria species. Even though S. pneumoniae is a pathogen commonly found in pneumonia, this patient's preceding influenza, concurrent toxic shock syndrome, and presence of gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters indicate Staphylococcus.

E) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of elongation factor 2 is achieved through ribosylation of adenosine diphosphate, which eventually causes cell death due to inhibited protein synthesis. This process is mediated by Diphtheria toxin and exotoxin A, produced by C. diphtheriae and P. aeruginosa, respectively. Although P. aeruginosa is a common cause of pneumonia, neither of these species would appear as gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci in clusters.
questions.hint: The patient has signs and symptoms of bacterial pneumonia (dyspnea, fever, productive cough) and toxic shock syndrome (fever, hypotension, desquamative rash), which developed shortly after experiencing symptoms of influenza. Staphylococcus aureus, a gram-positive, coagulase-positive coccus that grows in clusters, is one of two bacterial species that cause toxic shock syndrome and is also a common cause of bacterial pneumonia secondary to an influenza infection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of malaise and a painful, pruritic rash on his lower back and thighs. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. Skin scrapings from the thigh grow neutral colonies on MacConkey agar. The colony-producing bacteria are oxidase-positive. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical symptoms (mild fever, pruritic rash, and skin eruptions) are classical findings of hot tub folliculitis, an infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. While typically dependent on direct inoculation (such as nail puncture wounds) or an immunocompromised host to cause an infection, the most common route of pseudomonal infection in immunocompetent hosts is contact with water (hot tub, lake, pool). Pseudomonal folliculitis is a self-limiting condition, but antibiotic treatment may be warranted in severe cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Infections following cat bites are most commonly caused by Pasteurella multocida. Unlike this patient's multiple, pruritic skin eruptions, an infection typically causes painful cellulitis at the inoculation site. Despite their gram-negative nature, Pasteurella spp. do not grow on MacConkey agar. Cat bites can also cause cat scratch disease due to transmission of Bartonella henselae . However, while B. henselae are gram-negative bacteria, they are oxidase-negative organisms. Furthermore, the location of the papulopustular eruptions and the absence of regional lymphadenopathy are not consistent with cat scratch disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse poses a risk for sexually transmitted diseases such as syphilis (caused by Treponema pallidum). Secondary syphilis presents with fever, malaise, and a polymorphic disseminated rash that often involves the trunk. However, this patient's rash is typically nonpruritic and follows the development of a primary genital lesion (chancre). Moreover, T. pallidum is best viewed with darkfield microscopy and in vitro cultivation of the organism is not possible. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is not transmitted via sexual intercourse.

D) INCORRECT:

The fungus Sporothrix schenckii can be transmitted through puncture wounds caused by rose thorns. Cutaneous sporotrichosis typically manifests as erythematous nodules or ulcers at the initial site of exposure (typically the upper extremity), unlike the multiple, pruritic skin eruptions seen on this patient's thigh. Moreover, MacConkey agar is used to evaluate bacteria, not fungi.
Image Description:

A linear sporotrichoid spread is visible along the draining lymphatics. Some lesions have a nodular appearance, while others show ulceration.


This is the characteristic clinical picture of a lymphogenic spreading sporotrichosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Several bacterial infections can be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact, including staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infections such as impetigo or folliculitis. However, gram-positive bacteria do not grow on MacConkey agar. Skin-to-skin contact is not a likely risk factor for this patient's skin infection, which is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Further skin infections resulting from direct skin-to-skin contact include tinea (fungal) infections, certain viral infections (e.g., HPV), and scabies (mite bites). Growth on MacConkey agar would not be observed.

F) INCORRECT:

Outdoor activities like camping increase the risk for tick-borne illnesses, such as Lyme disease (caused by Borrelia burgdorferi) or Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF; caused by Rickettsia rickettsii). Although both conditions can cause malaise, fever, and rash, neither would present with the painful, pruritic skin eruptions seen in this patient. Early Lyme disease manifests with a painless “bull's eye” rash, whereas RMSF shows a blanching macular rash that spreads from wrists and ankles to the trunk. Infection with R. rickettsii and B. burgdorferi is typically confirmed by serological testing, and neither pathogen is known to grow on MacConkey agar.
questions.hint: MacConkey agar only allows growth of gram-negative organisms. While lactose-fermenting bacteria produce bright pink colonies on this agar, lactose nonfermenters grow in neutral colors. This patient's papulopustular skin eruptions are most likely caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative, lactose non-fermenting, oxidase-positive bacillus.

questions.text: Four days after being admitted to the hospital for widespread second-degree burns over his arms and thorax, a 29-year-old man develops a fever and wound discharge. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F). Examination shows a discolored burn eschar with edema and redness of the surrounding skin. The wounds have a sickly, sweet odor. A culture of the affected tissue grows an aerobic, gram-negative rod. The causal pathogen most likely produces which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetanospasmin is an exotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani. C. tetani spores can enter human tissue through any breach of the skin barrier, such as wounds, burns, bites, or injections. However, infection with this pathogen would manifest with signs of tetanus (e.g., spastic paralysis, trismus), which are not present in this patient. Furthermore, C. tetani is a gram-positive, obligate anaerobe, not a gram-negative aerobe.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptolysin O is one of the virulence factors produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. Although S. pyogenes is a common cause of (nosocomial) skin infections, it is a gram-positive coccus, in contrast to the gram-negative rod that was grown on this patient's culture.

C) CORRECT:

Phospholipase C, which degrades cellular membrane phospholipids, is one of several toxins produced by P. aeruginosa. This pathogen is one of the organisms that most frequently cause wound infection and sepsis in patients with burn wounds. Because burns damage the physical barrier, impair perfusion, and can suppress the immune system, they predispose to infection.

Other virulence factors of P. aeruginosa include endotoxin (causes fever, shock), exotoxin A (inactivates EF-2), and blue-green pigments (pyoverdine and pyocyanin). P. aeruginosa also produces 2-aminoacetophenone, which is responsible for the sweet, grape-like odor of infected wounds.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxin B is an exotoxin produced by Clostridioides difficile, which causes pseudomembranous colitis and diarrhea, not the nosocomial cutaneous infection seen here. Furthermore, Clostridioides difficile is a gram-positive, obligate anaerobe, not a gram-negative aerobe.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha toxin is an important toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens. C. perfringens is a known cause of cutaneous infections, but, as an anaerobic pathogen, it more commonly infects deep penetrating wounds (causing gas gangrene) rather than burn wounds.
