Furthermore, C. perfringens is gram-positive, not gram-negative.

F) INCORRECT:

Protein A, which inhibits phagocytosis, is one of the virulence factors produced by Staphylococcus aureus. Although S. aureus is one of the most common causes of (nosocomial) skin infections and burn wound infections, it is a gram-positive coccus, while this patient's culture grew a gram-negative rod.
questions.hint: This patient has developed a secondary infection of his burn wounds while in the hospital. The characteristic sweet odor and the aerobic, gram-negative rod on culture make Pseudomonas aeruginosa the most likely causal organism.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, nausea, and flank pain. She has multiple sclerosis and a chronic indwelling bladder catheter for neurogenic bladder dysfunction. One week ago, she was discharged from the hospital after treatment for a multiple sclerosis flare. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the right costovertebral area. Urine cultures grow a non-lactose fermenting, oxidase-positive, gram-negative rod. The causal organism of this patient's current condition most likely produces which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid is a surface protein found exclusively in the cell walls of gram-positive bacteria. However, Gram staining of this patient's urine showed a gram-negative rod.

B) INCORRECT:

K capsule is a cell surface antigen specific to Escherichia coli. E. coli is a gram-negative rod and the most common cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, which makes it a reasonable consideration given this patient's treatment history. However, E. coli is a lactose-fermenting bacterium, whereas the causative organism of this patient's UTI is non-lactose fermenting.

C) INCORRECT:

Urease-producing organisms include Proteus spp., Ureaplasma spp., Nocardia spp., Cryptococcus spp., Helicobacter pylori, Bacteroides spp., S. epidermidis, and S. saprophyticus. However, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the causative organism of this patient's urinary tract infection, does not produce urease.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxin B is produced by Clostridioides difficile, a gram-positive rod that causes diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. C. difficile is not associated with urinary tract infection. Furthermore, this patient's urine culture revealed a gram-negative rod.

E) CORRECT:

Pyoverdine is a pigment produced by some species of Pseudomonas, including P. aeruginosa, that acts mainly as an iron-chelating agent (siderophore). Together with pyocyanin, pyoverdine serves as an essential virulence factor of this bacterium, ensuring its survival and proliferation in iron-deficient conditions, regulating the production of other virulence factors, and supporting the development of biofilms.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This non-lactose fermenting, oxidase-positive, gram-negative rod is a common cause of nosocomial UTIs, especially in patients with chronic indwelling catheters.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with fever, abdominal pain, and nausea for the past 2 days. The pain started in the right lower abdomen but has now progressed to diffuse abdominal pain. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F). Physical examination shows generalized abdominal tenderness with rebound, guarding, and decreased bowel sounds. She is taken for an emergency exploratory laparoscopy, which shows a perforated appendix with an adjacent abscess and peritoneal inflammation. Cultures from the abscess fluid grow gram-negative rods that have the ability to survive in bile and do not produce catalase or superoxide dismutase. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy against the cultured organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glycopeptides (e.g., vancomycin) are effective against gram-positive bacteria but ineffective against gram-negative bacteria because the outer lipopolysaccharide membrane of gram-negative bacteria acts as a barrier that prevents large molecules such as glycopeptide antibiotics from reaching the target site in the cell wall.

B) INCORRECT:

Aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) are effective for the treatment of infections caused by aerobic, gram-negative bacteria but are ineffective against anaerobic species because the uptake of aminoglycosides into the bacterial cell is a highly energy-dependent process that can only occur in aerobic bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

First-generation cephalosporins (e.g., cefazolin) have limited activity against gram-negative bacteria and most cephalosporins (with the exception of cefoxitin and cefotetan) have limited anaerobic coverage.

D) CORRECT:

Antibiotics that are effective against anaerobic bacteria include metronidazole, clindamycin, carbapenems, and extended-spectrum penicillins (e.g., ampicillin, piperacillin). Since gram-negative bacteria have a wide periplasmic space often containing beta-lactamase, extended-spectrum penicillins are combined with a beta-lactamase inhibitor (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam, piperacillin-tazobactam) to improve gram-negative coverage. Bacteroides spp. have the highest rates of antibiotic resistance among all anaerobic bacteria and more than 90% of B. fragilis strains produce beta-lactamase.

E) INCORRECT:

Monobactams (e.g., aztreonam) are primarily effective against aerobic gram-negative rods because this antibiotic class has a high affinity specifically for penicillin-binding protein 3 (PBP-3), which is the predominant penicillin-binding protein (PBP) found in these bacteria. Monobactams have a low affinity for the PBPs found in anaerobic bacteria and gram-positive rods and are therefore ineffective against these pathogens.
questions.hint: Bacteria that are both catalase-negative and superoxide dismutase-negative are obligate anaerobes. The gram-negative, bile-resistant, obligate anaerobe is Bacteroides fragilis, which is a normal part of the intestinal flora but can cause peritonitis and abscess formation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent right knee pain and swelling for 2 weeks. Six months ago, he had a total knee replacement because of osteoarthritis. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 139/84 mm Hg. Examination shows warmth and erythema of the right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. His leukocyte count is 14,500/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 50 mm/hr. Blood cultures grow gram-positive, catalase-positive cocci. These bacteria grow on mannitol salt agar without color change. Production of which of the following is most important for the organism's virulence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Protein A is a virulence factor that protects Staphylococcus aureus from phagocytosis by binding to the Fc region of IgG antibodies and thus preventing opsonization and complement activation. S. aureus is one of the most common causative pathogens of prosthetic joint infections. However, this organism typically causes early-onset infections (i.e., in the first 3 months following placement), rather than the delayed-onset infection seen here. Additionally, blood cultures would reveal gram-positive, catalase-positive cocci in clusters that produce typical gold-yellow colonies on mannitol salt agar.

B) INCORRECT:

The Vi capsule is a virulence factor that protects Salmonella typhi from phagocytosis. S. typhi is a very rare causative agent of prosthetic joint infections, which this patient presents with. However, this patient has not reported any risk factors for infection with S. typhi (i.e., sickle cell disease, a recent history of enteric fever, travel to an endemic region). Additionally, blood cultures would show gram-negative flagellated rods.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas exotoxin A is a virulence factor of Pseudomonas aeruginosa that inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), thereby causing host cell death. P. aeruginosa is a less common causative agent of prosthetic joint infections, which this patient presents with. Moreover, bony infections due to this organism are usually associated with a puncture wound, often from stepping on a nail, which this patient hasn't reported. Additionally, blood culture results would show gram-negative bacilli.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcal M protein is a virulence factor that protects Group A streptococci (GAS) from phagocytosis by inhibiting bacterial opsonization and alternative complement pathway activation. While GAS can cause necrotizing soft tissue infections, manifesting with warmth, erythema, and limited range of motion, the presentation would be much more acute than seen in this patient (i.e., hours rather than weeks), with additional physical exam findings such as crepitus and bullae. Moreover, blood culture results would show gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci in chains.

E) CORRECT:

Exopolysaccharides are a primary component of biofilm, which is the major virulence factor of Staphylococcus epidermidis, a part of the natural skin flora and one of the leading causative pathogens of foreign body-related infections. Biofilm consists of an extracellular matrix of polysaccharides and protein, which both adheres S. epidermidis to the foreign material and protects the bacteria from host defenses and antimicrobial agents. The typical presentation of infection with S. epidermidis is a delayed-onset, highly resistant infection in patients with indwelling medical devices (e.g., prosthetic orthopedic devices, intravascular catheters, and cerebral shunts), as seen here. Other bacteria that use biofilms include Pseudomonas aeruginosa and viridans streptococci.
questions.hint: The patient's blood culture shows gram-positive, catalase-positive cocci that do not ferment mannitol (i.e., do not produce a color change on mannitol salt agar), which is characteristic of Staphylococcus epidermidis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramping for the past 24 hours. She recently went to an international food fair. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows increased bowel sounds. Stool cultures grow gram-positive, spore-forming, anaerobic rods that produce alpha toxin. The responsible organism also causes which of the following physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse, flaccid bullae are seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), which is caused by Staphylococcus aureus. While these bacteria are a common cause of acute gastroenteritis, Staphylococcus aureus is a β-hemolytic, catalase-positive, gram-positive coccus that grows in clusters.

B) INCORRECT:

Facial paralysis can be observed in Guillain Barré syndrome, which may occur as a complication of Campylobacter jejuni enteritis, the most common pathogen responsible for foodborne gastroenteritis in the US. While this infection also manifests with diarrhea, it most often causes bloody diarrhea, not the watery diarrhea seen in this patient. Moreover, Campylobacter jejuni is a comma-shaped, gram-negative rod, while this patient's culture has grown gram-positive, spore-forming, anaerobic rods.

C) CORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens, the organism responsible for this patient's symptoms, can also cause gas gangrene, which classically manifests with subcutaneous emphysema and palpable crepitus. The spores of these obligate anaerobic rods survive in undercooked food; when ingested, bacteria release heat-labile enterotoxins that cause food poisoning with watery diarrhea and severe abdominal cramping. This condition is rarely complicated by a syndrome that resembles necrotizing enteritis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bacterial culture (Gram stain; very high magnification; cultivated in Schaedler broth)

Multiple gram-positive, rod-shaped Clostridium perfringens bacteria are seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Rose spots can be caused by infection with Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi, which are transmitted via the fecal-oral route. While these organisms can cause diarrhea, (para)typhoid fever typically progresses over the course of weeks. Moreover, these organisms are gram-negative and non-spore-forming, which would not be consistent with the gram-positive, spore-forming bacteria seen in this patient's culture.
Image Description:

There are several small, bright red macules on the skin of the chest and shoulders. This skin finding is accompanied by fever.

These findings are a rare skin manifestation of typhoid fever, caused by the bacterium Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi.

E) INCORRECT:

A petechial rash can be observed in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which is most commonly caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). However, EHEC typically causes bloody diarrhea, which is not present in this patient. The only type of E. coli that causes watery diarrhea is enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), the most frequent cause of traveler's diarrhea. Since this patient has no history of recent travel, this diagnosis is also unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and stool culture are consistent with Clostridium perfringens enterocolitis.

questions.text: A 3-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of irritability and feeding intolerance for 1 day. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F). Physical examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. A photomicrograph of a Gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid is shown. Further evaluation shows that the organism expresses the K1 capsular polysaccharide. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis is one of the most common bacterial causes of meningitis in the adult and elderly population but is rare in the neonatal period. Moreover, the Gram stain of this patient's CSF is inconsistent with Neisseria species, as they are gram-negative diplococci rather than gram-negative rods. Even though N. meningitidis does have a capsule that prevents phagocytosis, it does not contain K1 polysaccharide.

B) CORRECT:

The gram-negative rod Escherichia coli is one of the most common bacterial causes of neonatal meningitis. In the majority of cases, infection is caused by strains of E. coli that express the K1 capsular polysaccharide. This virulence factor provides resistance to phagocytosis and antibacterial factors in the serum, facilitating the invasion of bacteria. In this patient, antibiotic treatment with ampicillin should be initiated as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes is one of the most common bacterial causes of neonatal meningitis, particularly in premature infants with very low birth weight. However, L. monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod and therefore is not consistent with the organisms revealed by the Gram stain here. Moreover, important virulence factors of L. monocytogenes include listeriolysin O and actin rockets, but not K1 capsular polysaccharide.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a rare cause of meningitis in the neonatal period. Although the gram-negative rods found in this patient's CSF are consistent with Pseudomonas species, expression of K1 capsular polysaccharide would not be expected. Instead, P. aeruginosa produces a mucoid polysaccharide capsule that facilitates adherence to mucoid surfaces while preventing phagocytosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Salmonella typhi is an encapsulated, gram-negative rod that is consistent with the Gram stain here. However, infection with S. typhi is associated with typhoid fever rather than neonatal meningitis. Typhoid fever progresses from gradually rising body temperature and bowel abnormalities to persistent fever with rose-colored spots, yellow-green diarrhea, the characteristic typhoid tongue, and neurological symptoms. Moreover, S. typhi produces Vi capsular polysaccharide, not K1 capsular polysaccharide.

F) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a rare cause of meningitis in the immediate neonatal period. While this organism is encapsulated, Gram stain would reveal gram-negative coccobacilli rather than the gram-negative rods seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae belongs to the family of group B streptococci, which are the most common cause of neonatal meningitis. However, S. agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus and therefore is not consistent with the organisms revealed by the Gram stain here. Although S. agalactiae does exhibit a protective capsule that functions as a virulence factor, K1 capsular polysaccharides are not associated with it.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Streptococcus (Gram stain)

The chains of bluish-purple (gram positive) cocci seen on this Gram stain are characteristic of the genus Streptococcus.
questions.hint: Irritability, difficulty feeding, fever, and a bulging anterior fontanelle in a newborn should raise concern for neonatal meningitis. Based on the Gram stain, the causal pathogen is a gram-negative rod.

questions.text: A previously healthy 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, nausea, and myalgia for the past day. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 77/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae over the anterior chest and abdomen. Blood culture grows an organism on Thayer-Martin agar. Which of the following virulence factors of the causal organism is most likely responsible for the high mortality rate associated with it?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid is a cell surface protein in gram-positive bacteria. It acts as an antigen that induces cytokine mediators of septic shock like TNF-α and IL-1. Although this patient has symptoms of septic shock, his blood culture grew an organism on Thayer-Martin agar, indicating the organism is a gram-negative bacterium from the Neisseria genus.

B) CORRECT:

Lipooligosaccharide (LOS) is an endotoxin found on the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria like Neisseria meningitidis. It is the primary virulence factor in gram-negative septic shock, as it induces the release of proinflammatory mediators including TNF-α, IL-1, and IL-6. Those mediators lead to high fever, tissue damage, and vasodilation, resulting in petechial bleeding and shock. This is responsible for the high mortality rate of meningococcal disease. Serum levels of LOS have been found to correlate with the severity of septic shock.

While meningococcal infection usually manifests with clinical features of meningitis (neck rigidity, altered mental status), it can also manifest solely as meningococcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A protease is a bacterial enzyme found in both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, including S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria species. It cleaves mucosal IgA and allows bacteria to adhere to mucous membranes. This patient's blood culture grew a Neisseria species, so IgA protease would be present. However, it is primarily a virulence factor for evading the host's defenses, it does not result in septic shock.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 is a superantigen released by S. aureus. It cross-links regions of T-cell receptors and MHC II cells outside of the antigen binding site to trigger an inflammatory cascade, leading to toxic shock syndrome. S. aureus does not grow on Thayer-Martin agar. It also does not typically manifest with petechiae. Furthermore, although this patient has signs of septic shock, he does not have the desquamating rash and multiorgan failure typically seen in toxic shock syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythrogenic exotoxin A is a superantigen produced by Streptococcus pyogenes that activates T cells and triggers a massive release of cytokines. This can result in streptococcal toxic shock-like syndrome, which typically manifests with fever, a maculopapular exanthem, and shock. However, this patient does not have a maculopapular exanthem but petechiae. Furthermore, S. pyogenes is a gram-positive organism and would not grow on Thayer-Martin agar.
questions.hint: This boy's high fever and positive shock index (pulse/systolic blood pressure > 1) indicate septic shock. The scattered petechiae should already raise suspicion of meningococcemia as the underlying cause. Meningococcemia is confirmed by the growth of the organism on Thayer-Martin agar, which is a selective medium that is used to isolate Neisseria species like Neisseria meningitidis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 17-year-old female college student comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and severe headache. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity and photophobia. Blood cultures are obtained and a lumbar puncture is performed. A Gram stain of cerebrospinal fluid shows gram-negative cocci in pairs. Which of the following virulence factors was most likely involved in the initial step of this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The phospholipase alpha toxin is produced by Clostridium perfringens, the leading mediator for myonecrosis (gas gangrene). However, it does not cause meningitis. N. meningitidis does not produce exotoxins.

B) INCORRECT:

Protein A is not produced by N. meningitidis. Rather, it is a potent virulence factor produced by S. aureus, a gram-positive coccus that arranges in clusters. N. meningitidis, however, does produce IgA protease. IgA protease protects the colonizing bacteria of the nasopharynx from host IgA. This facilitates infection of mucosal surfaces, such as the meninges.

C) INCORRECT:

Lipooligosaccharides (LOS; also known as endotoxins) are a component of the outer membrane in gram-negative bacteria. After cellular lysis or endocytosis, LOS are released into the serum. There, they strongly stimulate macrophages, tissue factor, and complement. These pathways ultimately lead to the clinical signs of shock such as fever, hypotension, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. N. meningitidis releases endotoxin, but relatively late in the course of invasive infection. Lipooligosaccharides are, therefore, not a crucial part of the first step in meningeal infection.

D) CORRECT:

Pili and certain proteins, e.g., opacity proteins, are important virulence factors for N. meningitidis as they allow the bacterium to adhere to and invade epithelial and endothelial cells. Colonization of the nasal epithelium is considered the first crucial step leading to clinically apparent infection. In a small proportion of individuals colonized with N. meningitidis, the bacteria invade the bloodstream and gain access to the brain, presumably via the brain postcapillary venules or the choroid plexus, to cause meningeal infection.

N. meningitidis is transmitted via respiratory or oral secretions of asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers of the organism. Living in crowded spaces, such as college dormitories, is an important risk factor for transmission.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample (Gram stain; 1000× magnification)

Gram-negative diplococci (examples indicated by arrowheads), the classic morphology of Neisseria meningitidis, are visible.

E) INCORRECT:

A small number of, especially virulent, strains of N. meningitidis strains are capable of forming a biofilm. The biofilm is very effective at protecting the bacteria from antibiotics. Moreover, a biofilm decreases the effectiveness of circulating leukocytes in identifying and destroying bacterial cells. Although biofilm formation is important for prolonging the presence of nasopharyngeal colonization, a different virulence factor plays a more prominent role in initiating infection.

F) INCORRECT:

N. meningitidis has a polysaccharide capsule that plays a vital role in its pathogenicity by protecting it from antibody-/complement-mediated killing and inhibiting phagocytosis. Other bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae also rely on capsule formation. However, capsule formation does not play a role in the initial step of meningeal infection with N. meningitidis.
questions.hint: This girl presents with symptoms of meningitis (i.e., fever, headache, photophobia, nuchal rigidity). The presence of gram-negative diplococci on CSF analysis indicates that the causal organism is Neisseria meningitidis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever and left ear pain. Examination of the left ear shows a bulging tympanic membrane with green discharge. Gram stain of the discharge shows a gram-negative coccobacillus. The isolated organism grows on chocolate agar. The causal pathogen most likely produces a virulence factor that acts by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Binding of the Fc region of immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Binding of the Fc region of immunoglobulins is the mechanism of action of the virulence factor protein A, which is expressed by S. aureus and prevents effective opsonization and phagocytosis of microbial pathogens. Although S. aureus can cause otitis media, it appears as clusters of gram-positive cocci on Gram stain, not gram-negative coccobacilli. In addition, the medium commonly used to culture S. aureus is mannitol salt agar, not chocolate agar.

B) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of the 60S ribosome is the mechanism of action of Shiga toxin (produced by Shigella species), and Shiga-like toxin (produced by EHEC). Shigella and EHEC appear as gram-negative rods on Gram stain, not coccobacilli. In addition, infection with Shigella or EHEC typically causes bloody diarrhea, not otitis media.

C) INCORRECT:

Overactivation of adenylate cyclase is the mechanism of action of heat labile toxin (from ETEC), cholera toxin (from Vibrio cholerae), and pertussis toxin (from B. pertussis). These microbes appear as gram-negative rods on Gram stain, not coccobacilli. ETEC and V. cholerae can cause profuse watery diarrhea and B. pertussis can cause whooping cough. None of these pathogens causes otitis media.

D) CORRECT:

Hemophilus influenzae produces IgA protease, a virulence factor that mediates cleavage of secretory immunoglobulins (IgA antibodies). IgA protease thereby facilitates pathogen adherence to mucosal membranes (e.g., the middle ear mucosa and tympanic membrane), which are normally protected by IgA antibodies.

IgA protease is also produced by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria gonorrhea, and N. meningitidis.

E) INCORRECT:

Elongation factor can be inactivated by either diphtheria toxin (from C. diphtheriae) or exotoxin A (from P. aeruginosa). C. diphtheriae appears as gram-positive rods on Gram stain and causes diphtheria, not otitis media. The media commonly used to culture C. diphtheriae are Tellurite agar and Löffler medium, not chocolate agar. P. aeruginosa appears as gram-negative rods on Gram stain and can cause otitis externa, but it is not a common cause of otitis media. The medium commonly used to isolate P. aeruginosa is Cetrimide agar, not chocolate agar.
questions.hint: Chocolate agar is a growth medium enriched with hemin (factor X) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (factor V). It is used to isolate fastidious organisms like Haemophilus influenzae, a gram-negative coccobacillus that is a typical causative pathogen of otitis media.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-day history of fever, crampy abdominal pain, and blood-tinged diarrhea. He recently returned from a trip to Mexico. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation; bowel sounds are hyperactive. Stool cultures grow nonlactose fermenting, oxidase-negative, gram-negative rods that do not produce hydrogen sulfide on triple sugar iron agar. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Invasion of colonic microfold cells is the mechanism by which Shigella causes host illness. Shigella enters cells via pinocytosis before lysing vesicles and entering the cytoplasm. Once inside the cytoplasm, Shigella produces Shiga toxin and rapidly poisons the cell. This mechanism is key to Shigella's ability to cause disease even in cases of very small exposure to the bacteria (i.e., Shigella has a very low infectious dose). Once inside the colonic mucosa, Shigella travels from cell to cell via actin polymerization.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of host cytoskeleton organization via actin depolymerization is the mechanism of action of toxin B, secreted by Clostridioides difficile, the causative organism of pseudomembranous colitis. Pseudomembranous colitis may manifest with blood-tinged diarrhea. However, the main risk factor for the development of clostridium enterocolitis is prior antibiotic use, which this patient does not report. Furthermore, stool culture identified gram-negative rods, while C. difficile is a gram-positive rod.

C) INCORRECT:

Overactivation of adenylate cyclase is the mechanism of cholera toxin (produced by Vibrio cholerae) and of heat-labile toxin (produced by enterotoxigenic E. coli; ETEC). Both toxins increase cAMP, leading to higher chloride secretion with resulting water efflux. However, the result of such water efflux is profuse, nonbloody diarrhea, in contrast to this patient's blood-tinged diarrhea. Moreover, V. cholerae is oxidase positive and comma-shaped, not a rod; and E. coli, though rod-shaped, is a (fast) lactose fermenter.

D) INCORRECT:

Dissemination via the bloodstream is an aspect of Salmonella virulence. Salmonellosis is usually contracted after eating tainted poultry or eggs and manifests with bloody diarrhea, which is seen here. Salmonella, however, is an H2S producer when grown on TSI agar. Shigella, the most likely bacteria in this patient, moves between cells along the host cells' actin filaments rather than via the bloodstream. Usurping the host's cytoskeleton allows Shigella to evade circulating leukocytes.

E) INCORRECT:

Flagella-mediated gut colonization is an important component of Campylobacter jejuni virulence. Enteritis caused by this bacteria typically manifests with bloody diarrhea, which this patient has, but also includes high fever, myalgias, and malaise, which are not mentioned here. C. jejuni is oxidase positive, whereas the identified organism in this instance is oxidase negative.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody diarrhea, which is concerning for bacterial gastroenteritis. The most likely causal organism is Shigella, a rod-shaped, gram-negative, oxidase-negative, and nonlactose fermenting rod that does not produce H2S on triple sugar iron (TSI) agar.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician with a 3-day history of fever, right calf pain, and swelling. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Physical examination shows a 5 x 6-cm erythematous, warm, raised skin lesion with well-defined margins over the right upper posterior calf. The organism isolated from the lesion forms large mucoid colonies on blood agar. Further evaluation shows that the organism has a thick hyaluronic acid capsule. The causal organism of this patient's condition is most likely to have which of the following additional characteristics?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gamma hemolysis is characteristic of Enterococcus spp., Streptococcus bovis and coagulase-negative staphylococci (S. saprophyticus, S. epidermidis). Enterococcus can cause UTI, biliary tract infections, and subacute infective endocarditis (SBE) following genitourinary procedures. S. bovis can cause SBE in patients with colon cancer. S. saprophyticus causes UTI, and S. epidermidis causes infections of prosthetic devices (e.g, prosthetic joints, heart valves) and venous catheter-related bloodstream infection. None of these organisms cause skin infections such as erysipelas or form mucoid colonies since they are all noncapsulated. S. pyogenes, which is the most likely pathogen in this patient, is beta-hemolytic.

B) INCORRECT:

Bile solubility is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Virulent S. pneumoniae, which have capsules, can form mucoid colonies. However, S. pneumoniae typically causes pneumonia, otitis media, meningitis, or sinusitis. It would not cause skin infections such as erysipelas. S. pyogenes, which is the most likely pathogen in this patient, is not soluble in bile.

C) INCORRECT:

Novobiocin resistance is characteristic of Staphylococcus saprophyticus. S. saprophyticus causes UTI; it does not cause skin infections such as erysipelas. Moreover, S. saprophyticus does not form mucoid colonies because it is a noncapsulated bacterium. S. pyogenes, which is the most likely pathogen in this patient, does exhibit sensitivity to novobiocin.

D) CORRECT:

With the exception of Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus), most gram-positive bacteria, including Streptococcus pyogenes, are susceptible to bacitracin. Since both S. agalactiae and S. pyogenes are catalase-negative, coagulase-negative, beta-hemolytic, capsulated cocci that can form mucoid colonies, the susceptibility to bacitracin can be used to differentiate the two species. The other lab findings that differentiate S. pyogenes from S. agalactiae are a negative Hippurate test and a positive pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) test. S. pyogenes can cause pharyngitis, tonsillitis, scarlet fever, a broad spectrum of skin and soft tissue infections (e.g., impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis), toxic shock syndrome, and certain postinfectious immunological phenomena (e.g., PSGN, rheumatic fever).
Image Description:

Petri dish containing a growth medium (trypticase soy agar supplemented with defibrinated sheep's blood) that has been inoculated with Streptococcus pyogenes.

The yellowish halo surrounding the bacterial colonies indicates complete degradation (beta-hemolysis) of the red blood cells in those areas.

Beta-hemolysis is a characteristic feature of S. pyogenes.

E) INCORRECT:

A negative pyrrolidonyl arylamidase (PYR) test would be seen with capsulated, mucoid-colony forming bacteria Streptococcus agalactiae. However, S. agalactiae would cause pneumonia, meningitis, and/or sepsis in newborns. It does not cause skin infections such as erysipelas. S. pyogenes, which is the most likely pathogen in this patient, is PYR positive.

F) INCORRECT:

A positive coagulase test is characteristic of Staphylococcus aureus. S. aureus can cause cellulitis, which would present similarly with an erythematous, warm lesion. However, cellulitis affects the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue and is usually not well-demarcated. Moreover, S. aureus does not usually form mucoid colonies because it is typically noncapsulated; it usually forms small, yellow colonies. S. pyogenes, which is the most likely pathogen in this patient, is coagulase-negative.

G) INCORRECT:

Resistance to optochin is a characteristic of viridans streptococci (e.g., S. sanguis, S. mutans), which cause dental caries and subacute bacterial endocarditis, not skin infections such as erysipelas. Moreover, viridans streptococci would not form mucoid colonies because they are noncapsulated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with an erythematous, warm, raised skin lesion with well-defined margins, which are characteristics of erysipelas. The most common cause of erysipelas is group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes), a pathogen with a thick hyaluronic acid capsule that forms mucoid colonies.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man hospitalized for acute pancreatitis develops a high-grade fever and productive cough with thick sputum. Medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder. A sample of expectorated sputum is obtained and fixed to a microscope slide using heat. Crystal violet is applied to the slide, followed by iodine, then acetone, and lastly, safranin. A photomicrograph of the result is shown. Which of the following properties of this bacteria's cell wall is responsible for the color seen on staining?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The amount of peptidoglycan in the bacterial cell wall determines whether the Gram stain will be positive or negative. Gram-positive species, which have a thick peptidoglycan layer, retain the crystal violet and appear deep purple. Gram-negative species have a thin peptidoglycan layer and do not retain the crystal violet after washing with alcohol or acetone. Instead, lipopolysaccharides on the outer membrane of gram-negative organisms stain pink after the application of the counterstain (e.g., safranin, carbol fuchsin).

B) INCORRECT:

Lipopolysaccharides are a major component of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria. During Gram staining, lipopolysaccharides stain pink after the application of the counterstain.

C) INCORRECT:

Transmembrane lipoproteins (also known as proteolipids) are present in the bacterial cell membrane and are involved in signal transduction, molecular transport, bacterial conjugation, and cellular adhesion. However, these molecules are not responsible for the color seen on Gram staining.

D) INCORRECT:

Mycolic acid, which is a component of the cell wall in acid-fast bacilli (e.g., Mycobacterium spp., Nocardia spp.), stains pink-red on Ziehl-Neelsen staining and red-yellow on auramine-rhodamine staining. This scenario, however, describes Gram staining and the cell wall of K. pneumoniae does not contain mycolic acid.

E) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid, which is a cell wall component that acts as an antigen for Toll-like receptors, is present in gram-positive but not gram-negative bacteria.
questions.hint: This process is Gram staining. High-grade fever, productive cough, and alcohol use disorder, in conjunction with pink (gram-negative) rods on Gram staining, suggest infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of fever, vomiting, rash, and worsening confusion since this morning. On questioning, her mother reports that her last menstrual period was 1 week ago and that she recently started using tampons. She appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Her temperature is 40.4°C (104.7°F), pulse 174/minute, and blood pressure is 62/44 mm Hg. Examination shows oropharyngeal hyperemia and diffuse macular erythroderma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythrogenic toxin production is the primary cause of streptococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS). Streptococcal TSS occurs most frequently in the setting of invasive infection due to Streptococcus pyogenes. While the clinical presentation is similar to this patient's, with fever, shock, and rash, it usually follows a cutaneous infection (impetigo) and is not typically associated with tampon use.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipooligosaccharide is an endotoxin found on the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria like Neisseria meningitidis. It is the primary virulence factor in meningococcemia, which would manifest with high fever, confusion, and shock. However, petechiae would be expected instead of diffuse macular erythroderma, and meningococcemia is not typically associated with tampon use.

C) INCORRECT:

Unregulated B cell proliferation is the primary cause of certain leukemias and B-cell lymphomas. They are unlikely to present acutely with fever, rash, confusion, and shock and are not related to tampon use. B cells are not involved in the pathophysiology of TSS.

D) INCORRECT:

Generalized mast cell degranulation with subsequent release of histamine, cytokines, and proteases is seen in anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis can manifest with hypotension and vomiting. However, angioedema, urticaria, and wheezing would be expected instead of this patient's macular erythroderma and fever. Furthermore, another condition is much more likely to be associated with tampon use.

E) CORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a life-threatening systemic inflammatory reaction caused by bacterial exotoxins, e.g., toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) produced by Staphylococcus aureus. TSST-1 is a superantigen that triggers polyclonal T cell activation by binding to MHC II and T-cell receptors, resulting in the massive release of IL-2, IFN-γ, and TNF-α. This leads to the typical symptoms of high fever, rash, altered mental status, and shock. About half of TSS cases are caused by prolonged use of tampons over several days.
questions.hint: The sudden onset of high fever, diffuse macular erythroderma, confusion, and shock (hypotension and tachycardia) in a young girl who recently had her menstrual period raises concern for toxic shock syndrome (TSS) as a result of prolonged tampon use.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his babysitter because of lethargy and fever for 3 hours. He has not fully recovered from a middle ear infection that started a few days ago. The parents cannot be reached for further information. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity. A pathogen is isolated from the patient's cerebrospinal fluid that does not grow on regular blood agar plate but produces colonies when co-cultured with Staphylococcus aureus. Vaccination against the causative pathogen of this patient's current disease is most likely to also prevent which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial rhinosinusitis is commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae; however, it is specifically unencapsulated nontypeable H. influenzae (NTHi) that is responsible for this infection. The Hib vaccine consists of the type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate [PRP]) conjugated to a protein carrier such as the tetanus toxoid and therefore does not protect against any other serotypes.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial rhinosinusitis and also the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in this age group despite the pneumococcal vaccine. However, S. pneumonia grows on blood agar unlike the pathogen identified in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Croup is most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus, not Haemophilus influenzae. There is currently no standard vaccine against parainfluenza virus.

C) INCORRECT:

Influenza is caused by the influenza virus, which can be prevented by the flu vaccine. However, influenza is not caused by the bacterium Haemophilus influenzae.

D) CORRECT:

In unvaccinated children, epiglottitis is most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). Prior to the introduction of routine Hib vaccination, this bacterium was also the leading cause of pediatric bacterial meningitis, pneumonia, empyema, pericarditis, bacteremia, and septic arthritis. Routine childhood vaccination has decreased the incidence of epiglottitis significantly. Unencapsulated strains (not covered by the Hib vaccine) are still common causes of otitis media, sinusitis, conjunctivitis, and pneumonia, especially in the pediatric population.

E) INCORRECT:

Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. This patient's condition is not caused by H. ducreyi and there is not a standard vaccine against it. The Hib vaccine does not produce immunity against other Haemophilus species.

F) INCORRECT:

Impetigo is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, and a minority of cases are due to β-hemolytic streptococci. A vaccine against S. aureus does not currently exist. Standard vaccination is recommended for α-hemolytic Streptococci pneumoniae but not β-hemolytic streptococci (although trials exist). Unlike the findings here, all of these bacteria grow independently on blood agar, leaving a clear zone surrounding the colonies due to the lysis of surrounding RBCs. Haemophilus influenzae does not cause impetigo or other skin infections.
questions.hint: The pathogen in question is likely Haemophilus influenzae. It requires factors X (hematin) and V (NAD) for growth, which are not found in regular sheep blood agar. Staphylococcus aureus produces NAD and lyses erythrocytes in the agar, which releases hematin into the surrounding growth medium and allows Haemophilus to grow within the hemolytic zone of S. aureus. This is known as the satellite phenomenon or satellitism. This child likely did not receive Hib vaccination.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe left ear pain and drainage for 3 days. He has a history of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. He appears uncomfortable. Physical examination of the ear shows marked periauricular erythema, exquisite tenderness on palpation, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. The most likely causal pathogen produces an exotoxin that acts by a mechanism most similar to that of a toxin produced by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces diphtheria toxin, which inhibits protein synthesis and induces cell death by the same mechanism as Pseudomonas exotoxin A, via inactivation of elongation factor 2. C. diphtheriae causes diphtheria. Other virulence factors produced by P. aeruginosa include phospholipase C, endotoxins, and pigments (pyoverdin and pyocyanin).

B) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis produces pertussis toxin, which increases the level of cAMP and impairs phagocytosis by overactivating adenylate cyclase. B. pertussis causes whooping cough (pertussis). P. aeruginosa does not produce an exotoxin with a similar mechanism of action to pertussis toxin.

C) INCORRECT:

Shigella dysenteriae produces Shiga toxin, which inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating the 60S ribosome (cleaves adenine from the ribosomal RNA) and causes cell death. S. dysenteriae causes bloody diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome. P. aeruginosa does not produce an exotoxin with a similar mechanism of action to Shiga toxin.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus produces toxic shock syndrome toxin 1 (TSST-1), which binds to MHC II and T-cell receptors, resulting in polyclonal T-cell activation and massive release of cytokines. This leads to the development of toxic shock syndrome, which is characterized by sudden onset of fever, rash, hypotension, renal failure, and changes in mental status. P. aeruginosa has an endotoxin that can induce fever and shock, but it does not produce an exotoxin with a similar mechanism of action to TSST-1.

E) INCORRECT:

Clostridium tetani produces tetanospasmin, a protease that cleaves SNARE proteins, thereby preventing the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters and causing tetanus. P. aeruginosa does not produce an exotoxin with a similar mechanism of action to tetanospasmin.

F) INCORRECT:

Bacillus anthracis produces edema toxin, which mimics adenylyl cyclase and increases the level of cAMP. This results in tissue edema and impaired chemotaxis of macrophages and neutrophils. B. anthracis can cause cutaneous, inhalational, or intestinal anthrax. P. aeruginosa does not produce an exotoxin with a similar mechanism of action to edema toxin.
questions.hint: Unilateral severe ear pain and drainage with granulation tissue in the external auditory canal in a patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus are highly suggestive of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This organism produces exotoxin A, which induces host cell death via inhibition of elongation factor 2.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of profuse watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps. Four days ago, he returned from a backpacking trip across Southeast Asia. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Stool culture shows gram-negative, oxidase-positive, curved rods that have a single polar flagellum. The pathogen responsible for this patient's condition most likely has which of the following characteristics?

choices.text: Requires low infectious dose to establish infection
Acts by activation of guanylate cyclase
Causes necrosis of Peyer patches of distal ileum
Grows well in medium with pH of 9

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shigella is an example of a bacterium that is highly resistant against stomach acid, and thus it requires a very low infectious dose to establish gastroenteritis. However, bloody diarrhea would be expected, whereas this patient reported profuse watery diarrhea. Furthermore, although Shigella bacteria would appear as gram-negative rods on stool culture, they are not curved, do not have flagella, and are oxidase-negative.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) causes traveler's diarrhea. It produces heat labile toxin and heat stable toxin, which respectively activate adenylate cyclase and guanylate cyclase, resulting in watery diarrhea. However, although ETEC would appear as a gram-negative rod on stool culture, it is not curved, has no flagella, and is oxidase-negative. Vibrio cholerae permanently activates adenylate cyclase, not guanylate cyclase.

C) INCORRECT:

Salmonella typhi and Yersinia enterocolitica are examples of gram-negative bacteria that are known to migrate into Peyer patches of the distal ileum, which can lead to necrosis and result in bloody diarrhea. Patients with Salmonella typhi infection present with fever and constipation followed by diarrhea, while patients with Yersinia enterocolitica infection present with gastroenteritis and/or mesenteric lymphadenitis, which may mimic acute appendicitis. These organisms do not match the profuse watery diarrhea reported in this patient. Furthermore, unlike the pathogen isolated from this patient's stool, both S. typhi and Y. enterocolitica are oxidase-negative organisms with peritrichous flagella.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome typically follows gastroenteritis due to Campylobacter jejuni. Although C. jejuni appear as gram-negative and oxidase-positive bacteria with polar flagella under the microscope, they are s-shaped rather than curved, and patients often have bloody rather than profuse watery diarrhea.

E) CORRECT:

Vibrio cholerae is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, curved rod. It produces an enterotoxin, which permanently activates a GS protein and thereby results in increased intracellular cAMP levels. This leads to secretion of chloride ions and water in the intestines, resulting in the typical rice-water diarrhea. V. cholerae is acid-labile, growing well in an alkaline medium (e.g. with a pH of 9). Accordingly, stomach acidity provides a natural barrier against V. cholera, so that a high amount of pathogens are required to cause infection (high infectious dose). A decrease in gastric acidity (e.g., due to treatment with proton pump inhibitors) reduces the infectious dose significantly.
Image Description:

Scanning electron micrograph

Numerous curved (comma-shaped) vibrio cholerae bacteria can be seen.

F) INCORRECT:

Clostridioides difficile is an obligate anaerobe that can form spores in unfavorable environments. It can cause pseudomembranous colitis, which commonly manifests with abdominal cramps and watery diarrhea. However, C. difficile is a gram-positive rod, as opposed to the gram-negative pathogen isolated. Moreover, C. difficile infection typically follows antibiotic treatment.
questions.hint: This patient's stool microscopy findings correspond with the morphological appearance of Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the growth of an organism in different media. The organism is inoculated on a petri dish that contains heated sheep blood, vancomycin, nystatin, trimethoprim, and colistin. The resulting growth medium is incubated at 37°C. Numerous small, white colonies are seen after incubation for 48 hours. This organism is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis, a gram-negative bacterium that is susceptible to both trimethoprim and colistin and thus does not grow on Thayer-Martin agar. B. pertussis can instead be isolated on Bordet-Gengou agar or Regan-Lowe medium.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by Clostridioides difficile, a gram-positive bacterium that is susceptible to vancomycin and thus does not grow on Thayer-Martin agar. C. difficile can be cultured on several other media (e.g., blood agar).

C) INCORRECT:

Pontiac fever is caused by Legionella spp., which are gram-negative bacteria that are susceptible to both trimethoprim and colistin and thus do not grow on Thayer-Martin agar. Legionella can instead be isolated on charcoal yeast extract agar.

D) INCORRECT:

Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, a gram-positive bacterium that is susceptible to vancomycin and thus does not grow on Thayer-Martin agar. C. diphtheriae can instead be isolated on Tellurite agar or Löffler medium.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome is caused by enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli. E. coli is a gram-negative bacterium that is susceptible to both trimethoprim and colistin and thus does not grow on Thayer-Martin agar. E. coli can instead be isolated on MacConkey agar.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral thrush is caused by Candida spp. (especially Candida albicans). Candida spp. are susceptible to nystatin and thus do not grow on Thayer-Martin agar; they can be easily cultured on several other media (e.g., blood agar).

G) CORRECT:

Gonorrhea is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Unlike other gram-negative bacteria, Neisseria spp. are resistant to trimethoprim and colistin and thus selectively grow on Thayer-Martin agar.
questions.hint: The medium described is Thayer-Martin agar, which contains antimicrobial drugs that inhibit the growth of gram-positive bacteria (vancomycin), many gram-negative bacteria (colistin, trimethoprim), and fungi (nystatin), which favors the selective growth of one particular bacterial genus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and flank pain. Five days ago, he was catheterized for acute urinary retention. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F). Physical examination shows right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine studies show numerous bacteria and WBC casts. Urine culture on blood agar grows mucoid, gray-white colonies. Urine culture on eosin methylene blue agar grows purple colonies with no metallic green sheen. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proteus mirabilis is an oxidase-negative, gram-negative rod that causes nosocomial urinary tract infections. However, P. mirabilis is not a lactose fermenter and thus does not cause a color change to eosin methylene blue agar, nor does it have a thick polysaccharide capsule that results in the growth of mucoid colonies.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an oxidase-positive, gram-negative rod that causes nosocomial urinary tract infections. Though P. aeruginosa does have a thick polysaccharide capsule that results in the growth of mucoid colonies, it is not a lactose fermenter and thus does not cause a color change to eosin methylene blue agar.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis is a gram-positive, catalase-negative coccus that causes nosocomial urinary tract infections, especially after instrumentation of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract. However, E. faecalis is not a lactose fermenter and thus does not cause a color change to eosin methylene blue agar, nor does it have a thick polysaccharide capsule that results in the growth of mucoid colonies.

D) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, lactose-fermenting, rod-shaped bacillus with a polysaccharide capsule that can result in the growth of mucoid colonies. It is the most common cause of urinary tract infections. Like other lactose fermenters, E. coli causes eosin methylene blue agar to change in color to purple because it renders the surrounding medium acidic; however, the colonies have a characteristic metallic green sheen when grown on this agar, which is not seen in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Klebsiella is a gram-negative, lactose-fermenting, rod-shaped bacillus with a particularly thick polysaccharide capsule that results in the growth of mucoid colonies. Like other lactose fermenters, Klebsiella spp. cause eosin methylene blue agar to change in color to purple because they render the surrounding medium acidic. Urinary tract infections are the most common nosocomial infection caused by Klebsiella spp., as seen in this case. The majority of these infections are caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. Treatment is typically antibiotic therapy with a fluoroquinolone or 3rd-generation cephalosporin, though the incidence of infections by extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing bacteria is increasing.

Klebsiella spp. also cause aspiration pneumonia (typically lobar pneumonia), lung abscesses, and liver abscesses, particularly among patients with alcohol use disorder and diabetes.
questions.hint: This man has nosocomial acute pyelonephritis after recent urinary catheterization. The mucoid appearance of the colonies is due to the presence of a thick polysaccharide capsule. The growth pattern on eosin methylene blue agar indicates that the causal pathogen is a lactose fermenter.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of a two-day history of fever, malaise, headaches, and confusion. She recently immigrated from rural China and her immunization status is unknown. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity and photophobia. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a neutrophil count of 1,500/mm3. Cerebrospinal fluid cultured on Thayer-Martin agar and normal sheep blood agar shows no growth. However, when the sheep blood agar sample is heated, numerous non-hemolytic, opaque, cream-colored colonies grow. Which of the following characteristics best describes the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative coccobacillus that requires factors X (hematin) and V (NAD) for growth. Because this organism is incapable of hemolysis on its own, red blood cells must be lysed by slow heating in order to release these molecules into the growth medium and make them available for bacterial metabolism. Without factors X and V, H. influenzae will not grow. When exposed to these factors, the bacteria can reproduce, which can be seen as the growth of cream-colored colonies. Meningitis caused by this organism is most common in patients who have not received the Hib vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative, facultative intracellular bacillus describes Legionella pneumophila. Unlike the organism isolated from the CSF cultures here, L. pneumophila is unable to grow on chocolate agar. L. pneumophila is best grown on charcoal yeast extract agar.

C) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococcus is characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus). S. pneumoniae is an α-hemolytic bacterium and is able to grow on both normal agar and chocolate agar. The bacteria in question that has infected this patient is non-hemolytic and cannot grow on conventional blood agar.

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus that can cause bacterial meningitis. Thayer-Martin agar is a selective medium that favors the growth of Neisseria species because it contains vancomycin (which inhibits the growth of gram-positive organisms) and nystatin (which inhibits the growth of fungi), along with trimethoprim and colistin (which together inhibit the growth of other gram-negative organisms). The organism isolated from the CSF cultures of the patient here did not grow on Thayer-Martin agar, making Neisseria infection unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive, facultative intracellular bacillus describes Listeria monocytogenes. Unlike the organism isolated from the CSF cultures of this patient, L. monocytogenes is a β-hemolytic bacterium and can grow on both normal agar and chocolate agar.
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms and laboratory findings consistent with bacterial meningitis. Chocolate agar is sheep blood that is slowly heated until red blood cells lyse and release factors V (NAD) and X (hematin).

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a routine well-child examination. She is given a vaccine that contains polyribosylribitol phosphate conjugated to a toxoid carrier. The vaccine is most likely to provide immunity against which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae infections can be prevented with pneumococcal conjugate vaccines. Like the vaccine this patient received, pneumococcal vaccines are derived from purified capsular antigens. In order to elicit an immune response in infants and toddlers, the capsular antigens are conjugated to inactivated diphtheria toxin to stimulate T cells, which causes a more rapid and long-lasting immune response. However, the pneumococcal antigens are not polyribosylribitol phosphate, meaning it is not the vaccine in question. Pneumococcal vaccination is most often administered at 2 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Poliovirus can be prevented with the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV, Salk strain). A live attenuated vaccine (the Sabin vaccine) is also available. Unlike the vaccine mentioned here, there is no immunogenic polysaccharide fragment in polio vaccines. Because the live attenuated vaccine is associated with the rare adverse effect of vaccine-induced polio, the inactivated vaccine is recommended (it does not carry a risk of causing polio). The first dose of IPV is administered at 2 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, which can be prevented with a vaccine containing the inactivated diphtheria toxin. Because there are no clinically available vaccines against this organism that rely on a capsular protein, it is not the vaccine in question here. The vaccine is usually administered along with the tetanus and pertussis vaccine as the DTaP vaccine at 2 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis virulence can be reduced by giving conjugate meningococcal vaccines to high-risk individuals. Capsular polysaccharides from the four most common virulent strains of N. meningitidis are typically conjugated to a diphtheria toxoid protein for enhanced immunogenicity. Unlike the vaccine mentioned here, the antigens are not polyribosylribitol phosphate. Furthermore, meningococcal vaccination is not routinely recommended at such an early age.

E) CORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) produces a polyribosylribitol phosphate capsule. This organism causes invasive diseases such as meningitis, epiglottitis, and septic arthritis, especially in early childhood. The PRP capsule is a strong virulence factor and plays a key role in the organism's pathogenicity by protecting it from complement-mediated lysis and phagocytosis. Vaccination is extremely effective at preventing these infections. Unencapsulated, nontypeable H. influenzae is not covered by the Hib vaccine; it is part of the normal nasopharyngeal flora and can cause otitis media, sinusitis, and conjunctivitis in children who have received the Hib vaccine.

The Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine contains the capsular polysaccharide conjugated to an immunogenic protein, such as diphtheria toxoid (conjugate vaccine). The Hib vaccine is generally administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth.

F) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis infection can be prevented with the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine. The aP vaccine contains the inactivated pertussis toxin rather than polyribosylribitol phosphate capsular proteins. The host immune system produces protective antibodies against the toxin, reducing the odds of developing an infection in cases of exposure to B. pertussis. The first dose of aP is administered at 2 months.
questions.hint: A polyribosylribitol phosphate (PRP) capsule is an important virulence factor for certain strains of this pathogen.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a headache, fever, and facial pain that started 10 days ago. The symptoms initially improved but have gotten significantly worse over the past 2 days. He has no history of major medical illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over both cheeks. Gram stain of a nasal swab shows small, gram-negative coccobacilli. Which of the following most likely accounts for this patient's infection with the causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phospholipase C is a virulence factor produced by several different bacteria, including P. aeruginosa, Clostridium spp., L. monocytogenes, and M. tuberculosis that facilitates invasion and growth within the host. Haemophilus influenzae, the most likely pathogen in this patient, does not produce phospholipase C.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperviscous secretions are characteristic of cystic fibrosis (CF) and cause decreased pathogen clearance, resulting in increased susceptibility to infections (including with Pseudomonas aeruginosa). However, this patient's symptoms are consistent with uncomplicated sinusitis, a common diagnosis among immunocompetent individuals, and he has no symptoms or history suggestive of CF (e.g., meconium ileus, failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea).

C) CORRECT:

Given this patient's age and immunization status, he has most likely received Haemophilus influenzae vaccination. However, the vaccine is only effective against encapsulated strains of H. influenzae (e.g., H. influenzae type b). Individuals thus remain vulnerable to non-typeable serotypes of H. influenzae because these serotypes lack a polysaccharide capsule. Non-typeable H. influenzae remains a common cause of acute otitis media, bronchitis, community-acquired pneumonia, and acute sinusitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Protein A is a virulence factor produced by Staphylococcus aureus that inhibits opsonization and phagocytosis by binding to the Fc region of IgG. Haemophilus influenzae, the most likely pathogen in this patient, does not produce protein A.

E) INCORRECT:

Splenic opsonization is impaired in patients with both anatomic asplenia (e.g., due to splenectomy) and functional asplenia (e.g., due to SCD) and results in greater susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms such as Haemophilus influenzae type B, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Neisseria meningitidis. However, this patient has no history of splenectomy or conditions associated with functional asplenia.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and clinical findings (maxillary tenderness, fever) are consistent with bacterial sinusitis, and the culture results are most consistent with  Haemophilus influenzae infection.

questions.text: A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fatigue, headache, and dry cough. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Chest examination shows mild inspiratory crackles in both lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates bilaterally. A Gram stain of saline-induced sputum shows no organisms. Inoculation of the induced sputum on a cell-free medium that is enriched with yeast extract, horse serum, cholesterol, and penicillin G grows colonies that resemble fried eggs. Which of the following organisms was most likely isolated on the culture medium?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative bacterium that causes pertussis, which typically manifests with a dry cough. However, infection with this pathogen is not associated with atypical pneumonia. Moreover, B. pertussis would appear as pink coccobacilli or diplococci on Gram staining, which are not seen in this patient's sample. Furthermore, this pathogen can be grown on Bordet-Gengou agar or Regan-Lowe medium, but not on Eaton agar.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a gram-positive, acid-fast bacillus that can cause chronic cough, fever, and fatigability. The pathogen also stains poorly on Gram staining and could possibly grow on a medium with penicillin G, as it is penicillin-resistant. However, M. tuberculosis is unlikely to have caused this patient's illness, as infection typically manifests with a productive cough, fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Moreover, active pulmonary tuberculosis is likely to manifest with hilar lymphadenopathy (primary) or an upper lobe cavitary lung lesion (reactivation). Lastly, it is best grown on Lowenstein-Jensen agar rather than Eaton agar.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlamydophila psittaci is an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes psittacosis, which typically manifests with atypical pneumonia. The pathogen is also known to stain poorly on Gram staining. Birds are the primary reservoir and infection spreads via inhalation of organisms from dried bird feces. There is no indication of exposure to an infected bird in this patient's history. Furthermore, Eaton agar will not grow C. psittaci.

D) CORRECT:

Long-standing cough, low-grade fever, malaise, and a chest x-ray that reveals findings that are markedly out of proportion to a patient's symptoms are highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia. The absence of organisms on Gram staining and growth of “fried-egg colonies” on Eaton agar suggest a Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection. M. pneumoniae is naturally resistant to penicillin because it lacks a cell wall. Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection should be treated with macrolides, tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline), or fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin).

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydophila pneumoniae is an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes upper and lower respiratory tract infections, including atypical pneumonia. The pathogen is also known to stain poorly on Gram staining. Like other Chlamydia spp., it lacks peptidoglycans in its cell wall and is therefore resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin). However, Eaton agar will not grow C. pneumoniae.

F) INCORRECT:

Coxiella burnetii is responsible for the zoonotic infection commonly known as Q fever, which can present with atypical pneumonia. However, cattle, sheep, and goats serve as the primary reservoirs for C. burnetii. This patient has no history of exposure to these animals or ingestion of unpasteurized milk products. Furthermore, C. burnetii is a gram-negative bacillus and would appear as pink rods on Gram staining, which were not seen in the sample here. Moreover, Eaton agar will not grow C. burnetii.

G) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae causes typical pneumonia, which is characterized by high fever, shaking chills, productive cough, decreased breath sounds on examination, and lobar consolidation on x-ray, none of which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, Haemophilus influenzae would appear as gram-negative coccobacilli on sputum sample microscopy and would grow best on chocolate agar buffered with factors V (NAD+) and X (hematin) rather than on Eaton agar.

H) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis is a pleomorphic, gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium. An infection with serotypes D–K can result in genitourinary infections (e.g., vaginitis, PID, urethritis), conjunctivitis, or infant pneumonia. This organism is unlikely to cause pneumonia in an adult. Furthermore, this pathogen will not grow on Eaton agar.

I) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli causes typical pneumonia, which is characterized by high fever, shaking chills, productive cough, decreased breath sounds on examination, and lobar consolidation on x-ray, none of which is seen in this patient. In addition, pneumonia that is caused by E. coli usually affects neonates, older adults, and hospitalized patients. Moreover, E. coli would be visible as pink rods on Gram staining, which were not seen in this patient's sample, and the pathogen does not grow on Eaton agar.

J) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila can cause atypical pneumonia, with respiratory symptoms similar to those seen in this patient (Legionnaires' disease). This pathogen is also known to stain poorly on Gram staining. However, Legionella is best grown on agar with charcoal yeast extract enriched with iron and cysteine, not Eaton agar. Moreover, in contrast to other types of atypical pneumonia, patients characteristically have a high fever and chills, often accompanied by diarrhea and confusion (due to hyponatremia), none of which is present in this patient. X-ray findings are variable but usually show patchy unilateral and lobar infiltrates that progress to consolidation rather than a diffuse interstitial infiltrate.

K) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that is most commonly transmitted by inhaling dust contaminated with the feces of infected birds (most commonly pigeons). Cryptococcus infection can manifest with pulmonary symptoms (pulmonary cryptococcosis), similar to the symptoms seen in this patient. In a patient with cryptococcal pneumonia, interstitial infiltrates are sometimes visible on chest x-ray, and Gram staining of the sputum sample might not show any pathogens. However, infection is extremely rare in immunocompetent individuals. Moreover, C. neoformans grows best on Sabouraud agar and is unlikely to grow on Eaton agar.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of atypical pneumonia. The medium containing yeast extract, horse serum, cholesterol, and penicillin G is Eaton agar.

questions.text:
An investigator is studying the antimicrobial resistance profile of a bacterial pathogen using disk diffusion testing. The pathogen is isolated onto agar plates and antibiotic wafers are added to the plates. The inhibitory zone diameters are then recorded and used to define susceptibility thresholds. The results of the testing for the pathogen shown:


Drug
Susceptibility



Penicillin G
Resistant


Cefazolin
Resistant


Doxycycline
Susceptible


Imipenem
Resistant


Azithromycin
Susceptible


Vancomycin
Resistant



Which of the following is most likely the organism being studied?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus may be sensitive to doxycycline, but all strains are resistant to azithromycin, whereas the organism in this case is not. Beta-lactam antibiotics, such as oxacillin, can be effective against methicillin-sensitive S. aureus (MSSA). However, beta-lactam drugs are not effective against methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA), which may be treated with a number of medicines, including doxycycline, vancomycin, and linezolid.

B) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum is sensitive to beta-lactam antibiotics, azithromycin, and doxycycline. The organism in question demonstrates resistance to beta-lactams, so it is not T. palladium.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is susceptible to carbapenems, extended-spectrum penicillins, and later-generation cephalosporins (e.g., cefepime or ceftazidime), unlike the organism isolated here. Multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas strains are increasingly prevalent in hospital settings and can be resistant to many conventional antibiotics, particularly penicillin and macrolides.

D) INCORRECT:

Borrelia spp. are susceptible to a variety of antibiotics, including beta-lactam antibiotics and tetracyclines. Doxycycline is considered the first-line drug, although penicillins or cephalosporins may be used in situations where doxycycline is contraindicated (e.g., pregnancy or for pediatric patients).

E) CORRECT:

Ureaplasma urealyticum, a bacterium closely related to Mycoplasma spp., is the most likely organism. Unlike many other species of bacteria, Ureaplasma has no cell wall. As beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems act by inhibiting the synthesis of peptidoglycan, a bacterial cell wall protein, these drugs are ineffective against Ureaplasma. Ureaplasma spp. are most commonly associated with urinary tract infections and pelvic inflammatory disease, and more rarely with more severe diseases such as pneumonia and meningitis. Both tetracyclines (doxycycline) and macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) are drugs of choice for treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis would be susceptible to certain penicillins and vancomycin, although vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) are increasingly prevalent. Ampicillin is the drug of choice in many enterococcal infections. Doxycycline used to be the drug of choice but now is used less commonly due to widespread resistance. Furthermore, enterococci spp. are intrinsically resistant to azithromycin, which the organism in this case is not. Cephalosporins and carbapenems are also ineffective against enterococci.
questions.hint: This pathogen shows resistance to antibiotics that affect the bacterial cell wall, which indicates that this organism lacks a cell wall.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, chills, myalgias, and joint pain 1 month after undergoing aortic prosthetic valve replacement due to high-grade aortic stenosis. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). She appears weak and lethargic. Physical examination shows crackles at both lung bases and a grade 2/6, blowing diastolic murmur over the right sternal border. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. The causal organism is most likely to have which of the following characteristics?

choices.text: Catalase-negative cocci that grows in 6.5% saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S. pneumoniae is an alpha hemolytic, optochin-sensitive diplococcus that may, in extremely rare cases, cause endocarditis. This patient more likely has prosthetic valve endocarditis from S. epidermidis, which is a gamma hemolytic coccus. Furthermore, pneumococcal pneumonia typically causes localized lung consolidation, which manifests in lung crackles in distinct regions, rather than the bibasilar crackles heard in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

S. epidermidis is a novobiocin sensitive, coagulase-negative, catalase-positive, gram-positive coccus with the capability of biofilm formation. As S. epidermidis is part of the normal skin flora, contamination of prosthetic devices (e.g., heart valves and hip implants) may occur during surgery.

Staphylococcus aureus is another common causal pathogen of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (i.e., within 60 days after implantation).

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus is a catalase-negative coccus that grows in 6.5% saline. It can cause infective endocarditis, typically following genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures. However, Enterococcus is only implicated in 8% of cases of endocarditis following valve replacement surgery. S. epidermidis, which is the most likely cause of endocarditis in this patient, is catalase-positive and does not grow in hypertonic saline.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a beta hemolytic, bacitracin sensitive bacterium that can cause acute rheumatic fever (ARF). ARF can manifest with fevers, myalgias, arthralgia, diastolic murmurs at the right sternal border due to aortic regurgitation, basilar lung crackles due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema, increased ESR, and leukocytosis. However, ARF is more common in children and adolescents. It rarely occurs in patients over the age of 45 years.

E) INCORRECT:
